The tech behind Artifact, the newly launched news aggregator from Instagram's co-foundersSarah Perez3/6/2023

As for Artifact's future, Systrom says he hopes it will become a place where users can go to discover content around their interests and be able to discuss them with others.

<div id="root">
	<div><!-- duplicate React-root div for styling -->
	<div class="content">
		<article class="article-container article--post ">
			<header class="article__header ">
	<div class="article__title-wrapper">
						<h1 class="article__title">The tech behind Artifact, the newly launched news aggregator from Instagram’s co-founders</h1>
		</div>

			<div class="article__byline-wrapper">
			
<div class="article__byline">
			<a href="https://techcrunch.com/author/sarah-perez/">
			Sarah Perez		</a>
		<span class="article__byline__meta">
							<a href="https://twitter.com/sarahintampa">@sarahintampa</a>
				<span class="text--green"> / </span>
						2 months		</span>
	</div>
		</div>
	
			<div class="article__featured-image-wrapper breakout">
			<img src="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/artifact-newspaper-icon.jpg?w=730" class="article__featured-image" />
		</div>
	</header>

			<div class="article-content">
				<p id="speakable-summary">Late last month, <a href="https://artifact.news/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Artifact</a>, a <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2023/01/31/instagrams-co-founders-introduce-a-new-social-app-for-news-reading/">personalized news reader </a>built by Instagramâ€™s co-founders, <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2023/02/22/instagrams-co-founders-personalized-news-app-artifact-launches-to-the-public-with-new-features/">opened</a> to the public. The launch was a surprise to many consumers, who wondered why the team behind one of the world’s most iconic social apps would return to startups to focus on one of the toughest areas instead: news. It’s an ecosystem where publishers are failing left and right and misinformation is rampant, as the founders surely saw themselves while working at Facebook.</p>
<p>In an interview, Instagram co-founder Kevin Systrom explains what drew him to this space and how his new app’s underlying technology will serve to differentiate it from the competition.</p>
<p>The startup’s existence, in some ways, can be credited to the COVID pandemic, as that’s what brought the Instagram co-founders, Systrom and Mike Krieger, back together. During the early days of the pandemic in 2020, the co-founders teamed up for the first time since leaving Facebook to create <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/04/18/instagram-founders-rt-live/">a COVID-19 dashboard called Rt.live</a> that tracked the spread of the virus across the U.S.</p>
<p>But in later months, other COVID trackers emerged and people were no longer as interested in tracking the virus’s spread on a state-by-state basis. Invigorated by the experience, the founders began then to think about returning to work on a “real company” instead of a public good side project.</p>
<h3>Machine learning is the “future of social”</h3>
<p><div id="attachment_2197512" style="width: 690px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img aria-describedby="caption-attachment-2197512" decoding="async" class="size-large wp-image-2197512" src="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?w=680" alt="AI - artificial intelligence CPU concept. Machine learning. CPU on the board with glow tracks. Background scientific concept in blue light, 3D illustration" width="680" height="453" srcset="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg 2121w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=1536,1024 1536w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=2048,1365 2048w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=1200,800 1200w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=50,33 50w" sizes="(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px" /><p id="caption-attachment-2197512" class="wp-caption-text"><strong>Image Credits:</strong> Usis / Getty Images</p></div></p>
<p>Deciding on their next act took time. The founders hacked around on stuff for a year and a half or so after their initial collaboration, Systrom says. The founder, who describes himself as a “very frameworks-driven person,” knew he wanted to do something that involved machine learning, having seen its power at Instagram.</p>
<p>“It was super fascinating to me to work on it at Instagram and watch it go from a company without machine learning to a company driven by machine learning,” he says. “I also witnessed the rise of TikTok and realized how important machine learning would be for the future of social.”</p><div class="piano-inline-promo"></div>
<p>He himself observed how social networking’s underlying graph had changed a lot over the years, watching as Facebook invented what’s now known as the “friend graph” — a user’s personal social network of real-life connections. Later, he saw Twitter pioneer the “follow graph,” or a graph of connections based on the user’s explicit choices of who they want to follow on a service. Then, at Instagram, Systrom saw firsthand the shift from the “follow graph” to the “inferred graph” or, rather, the “interest graph.”</p>
<p>This, he explains, was basically a “follow graph” powered by machine learning, instead of by users clicking a button.</p>
<p>The potential to leverage machine learning and an interest graph within a new product appealed to him, he says.</p>
<p>“We looked for an area that was social in nature, but where we could apply 20% new techniques — and that would be the machine learning side of what we’re doing,” Systrom says, describing how the founders narrowed their focus.</p>
<h3>Fixing a broken news ecosystem</h3>
<p><div id="attachment_2495453" style="width: 690px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img aria-describedby="caption-attachment-2495453" decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="size-large wp-image-2495453" src="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?w=680" alt="" width="680" height="453" srcset="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg 6000w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=150,100 150w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=300,200 300w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=768,512 768w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=680,453 680w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=1536,1024 1536w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=2048,1365 2048w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=1200,800 1200w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=50,33 50w" sizes="(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px" /><p id="caption-attachment-2495453" class="wp-caption-text"><strong>Image Credits:</strong> <a href="https://www.gettyimages.com/search/photographer?photographer=jayk7" target="_blank" rel="noopener">jayk7 <span class="screen-reader-text">(opens in a new window)</span></a> / Getty Images</p></div></p>
<p>The other consideration that prompted the founders’ interest in news, more specifically, was the potential impact if the app succeeded. They wanted to work on a startup they felt the world needed, Systrom says. No doubt, some of that interest may have been fueled by working at Facebook (now Meta), which had changed consumers’ news consumption behavior, impacting publishers as well as the spread of misinformation.</p>
<p>“It felt like our consumption of information — both factual, balanced, entertaining, etc. — had an existential crisis,” Systrom tells TechCrunch. Plus, he adds, “many of the people producing this content are going out of business.”</p>
<p>Meanwhile, on the consumer side of the news reading experience, there’s so much information swirling around that people don’t know what they can trust or which item to read. People are asking themselves if a link shared by a friend is actually legit and they’re wondering why they’re reading one article over the many others published on the same topic.</p>
<p>“It might be cheesy to say, because I’ve now said it a bunch of times, but I feel like the worst part about social media is that it’s social,” Systrom says. “I think the ‘social’ part of social media — for a long time, in terms of information consumption — has been a hack to filter for information that would be interesting to you. But we now don’t need that hack, because we can learn what’s interesting to you,” he continues. “We can quantify it. We can build profiles. And then we can serve you content that is both high-quality, balanced and interesting to you.”</p>
<p>This realization led to the creation of Artifact, a social news app powered by machine learning.</p>
<p><div id="attachment_2489439" style="width: 1960px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img aria-describedby="caption-attachment-2489439" decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="wp-image-2489439 size-full" src="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/artifact.jpg" alt="" width="1950" height="1398" srcset="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/artifact.jpg 1950w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/artifact.jpg?resize=150,108 150w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/artifact.jpg?resize=300,215 300w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/artifact.jpg?resize=768,551 768w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/artifact.jpg?resize=680,488 680w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/artifact.jpg?resize=1536,1101 1536w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/artifact.jpg?resize=1200,860 1200w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/artifact.jpg?resize=50,36 50w" sizes="(max-width: 1950px) 100vw, 1950px" /><p id="caption-attachment-2489439" class="wp-caption-text"><strong>Image Credits:</strong> Artifact personalization and stats</p></div></p>
<p>The app in some ways is very much like others that exist today, which have been founded in other countries, including ByteDance’s <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2018/11/17/jinri-toutiao-new-ceo/">Toutiao</a> in China, Japan’s <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/09/17/smartnews-u-s-app-unveils-new-features-for-the-elections-covid-19-and-local-weather/">SmartNews</a> and News Break, another personalized news reader <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/05/27/meet-news-break-the-news-app-trending-in-america-founded-by-a-chinese-media-veteran/">with Chinese roots</a>. Like its rivals, Artifact learns from user behavior, engagement and other factors in order to personalize which headlines are presented and in which order.</p>
<p>Despite this competitive landscape, Systrom believes U.S. news consumers want an option that’s actually based in their home market.</p>
<p>“They want a domestic player with a team they trust,” Systrom says, speaking to the news aggregation landscape in the U.S.</p>
<p>His comment is a timely one, given how tensions in the U.S. have been growing over China’s grip on the social networking market with TikTok. The short video app, which is often used as a source for news by Gen Z, is now banned on government phones and <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/06/technology/white-house-congress-on-tiktok.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">bipartisan legislation to further police it is in the works</a>.</p>
<h3>Clearing out the clickbait</h3>
<p>In addition to its locale, Systrom believes Artifact will be able to differentiate itself based on its unique combination of technology and taste — a directive that could also be used to describe Instagram’s founding for that matter.</p>
<p>Unlike Facebook — which became a platform by which any publisher could deliver news, and oftentimes clickbait — Artifact’s news sources are curated up front, the founder explains.</p>
<p>“When I say taste, I mean the top of the funnel in our system — the publishers we choose to distribute,” notes Systrom. “It’s not a free-for-all. We don’t crawl the entire web and just let everything go in.”</p>
<p>Instead, Artifact has selected the top publishers across different categories to fuel the content in the app. Customers can add their own paid subscriptions, as well. At this time, Artifact doesn’t sell those for a revenue share or involve itself in publishers’ ad sales, though one day that could change, depending on how the app chooses to monetize.</p>
<p>For now, however, the focus is on gaining traction with consumers and ensuring the app’s news sources are worth reading.</p>
<p><div id="attachment_2494033" style="width: 324px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img aria-describedby="caption-attachment-2494033" decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="vertical wp-image-2494033 size-large" src="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/IMG_5041.png?w=314" alt="" width="314" height="680" srcset="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/IMG_5041.png 1290w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/IMG_5041.png?resize=69,150 69w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/IMG_5041.png?resize=138,300 138w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/IMG_5041.png?resize=768,1665 768w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/IMG_5041.png?resize=314,680 314w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/IMG_5041.png?resize=709,1536 709w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/IMG_5041.png?resize=945,2048 945w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/IMG_5041.png?resize=554,1200 554w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/IMG_5041.png?resize=23,50 23w" sizes="(max-width: 314px) 100vw, 314px" /><p id="caption-attachment-2494033" class="wp-caption-text">Screenshot of Artifact app. <strong>Image Source:</strong> Artifact</p></div></p>
<p>“The line, internally…is we want a balanced ideological corpus, subject to integrity and quality,” Systrom says. “And the idea is not that we only choose left-wing, or we only choose right-wing. We drew the line at quality and integrity subject to a bunch of the metrics that a lot of these third-party fact-checking services have. The third-party services basically rate the integrity of different publishers based on their research and based on public events — like how quickly they correct their stories, whether their funding is transparent, all that kind of stuff,” he notes.</p>
<p>“You can claim it’s editorial,” he continues. “But it’s more about making sure that the set that we’re going to distribute and pour into this powerful machine — that can distribute content widely — that we’re being responsible by giving it content that isn’t going to be misinformation.”</p>
<p>Beyond the integrity of reporting, Artifact aims to deliver a news experience that’s more fulfilling.</p>
<p>“If you log on to a lot of these other sources, you get pretty clickbaity-stuff,” Systrom points out. “I’m not trying to throw shade on folks working in this area, but we wouldn’t work on it if we thought that it was solved. We focus a lot in our system on a different objective, which is this idea of value…if we put in the top-quality sources in these categories and we have coverage — whether it’s parenting or mental wellness, or exercise — that we can create a differentiated content set that feels much different than the front page of a major newspaper but also feels very different than a lot of the other aggregators,” he says.</p>
<p>Yet, even as the app personalizes its content selection to the end user, it doesn’t leave them in so-called “filter bubbles,” necessarily, as Facebook did. Instead, when users click on a headline to read a story, they’re shown the entire coverage across sources, allowing them to peruse the story from different vantage points.</p>
<h3>Artifact’s recommendation system</h3>
<p><div id="attachment_2477785" style="width: 690px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img aria-describedby="caption-attachment-2477785" decoding="async" loading="lazy" class="size-large wp-image-2477785" src="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/Product_Shot.jpeg?w=680" alt="Artifact displayed on smartphone laid on colored tiles/blocks" width="680" height="453" srcset="https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/Product_Shot.jpeg 1200w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/Product_Shot.jpeg?resize=150,100 150w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/Product_Shot.jpeg?resize=300,200 300w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/Product_Shot.jpeg?resize=768,512 768w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/Product_Shot.jpeg?resize=680,453 680w, https://techcrunch.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/Product_Shot.jpeg?resize=50,33 50w" sizes="(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px" /><p id="caption-attachment-2477785" class="wp-caption-text"><strong>Image Credits:</strong> Artifact</p></div></p>
<p>Systrom credits Toutiao for driving innovation in recommendation systems, noting that Toutiao essentially helped ByteDance give birth to TikTok. The technology developed for its news discovery was brought to its acquisition of Musical.ly, which became the Chinese app Douyin and its international counterpart TikTok.</p>
<p>But Systrom believes some of the machine learning that Artificat is doing is different.</p>
<p>“The machine learning that a lot of what we’re doing is based on was invented in 2017 at Google. It’s called the transformer…without that, GPT 3, 3.5 etc., wouldn’t exist. Without that, you wouldn’t have DALL-E. Without that, you wouldn’t have ChatGPT,” he says. “You’re inventing a core technology that can then be applied in many different ways.”</p>
<p>The app’s algorithms are focused on more than just tracking clicks and engagement. It weighs other factors, too, like dwell time, read time, shares, stories that get shared in DMs (private messages) and more.</p>
<p>“If you let your algorithm focus on clicks, it will end up serving clickbait. If you simply optimize for only what people have clicked on, you end up having tunnel vision,” Systrom explains.</p>
<p>The model additionally involves an algorithm called <a href="https://medium.com/analytics-vidhya/the-epsilon-greedy-algorithm-for-reinforcement-learning-5fe6f96dc870" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Epsilon-Greedy</a>.</p>
<p>“That’s a technical term for you taking some small portion of your time — like 10% or 20% — and you explore. You do something different than you would normally do…you go to the outside of the recommendation spectrum rather than the core of it,” Systrom says. “It’s shown many, many times, especially in reinforcement learning, that having this ‘explore’ budget we’ll call it, actually is optimal for users.”</p>
<p>That’s the same reason why TikTok <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2023/02/02/tiktok-introduces-a-strike-system-for-violations-tests-a-feature-to-refresh-the-for-you-feed/#:~:text=With%20the%20new%20refresh%20button,to%20their%20For%20You%20feed.">has begun testing tools that let users refresh their feeds</a>. Without the added spice of unexpected content, the video app’s suggestions had grown stale for some users.</p>
<p>But because the news changes every day, Artifact’s use of this Epsilon-Greedy algorithm also has to adapt as users’ own interests in topics grow and wane. For example, someone might be very into reading about the upcoming elections up until Election Day has passed. Or a new story may immediately capture their attention when it comes out of nowhere, as the story about the Chinese spy balloon did.</p>
<p>Artifact’s editorial consideration, if you can call it that, will also come into how the app’s algorithm is programmed, not just its publisher selections.</p>
<p>“Actually, building the algorithm is enormously editorial,” Systrom says. “Because what you choose to train your algorithm on — the objective function, the data you put in, the data you include, the data you don’t include — is all in editorial judgment. The way you weight different objectives.”</p>
<p>“All of the edge a company has is in its ability to wrangle the data in such a way that produces an outcome that’s optimal,” Systrom says.</p>
<p>If anything is Artifact’s secret sauce, it’s that.</p>
<h3>Does Artifact have a future?</h3>
<p>Whether all this tech and “taste” is enough for Artifact to succeed remains to be seen. The U.S. news aggregation landscape is not like China’s. And here, Artifact will have to fight against the default ways people access news, including through the news apps that come bundled with their smartphones, as well as the large internet portals like Google and Facebook, and some extent, YouTube and TikTok too.</p>
<p>At launch, Artifact added new functionality, including a new feature that allows users to track how they’ve been engaging with the app and its content in a metrics section, which shows a list of publishers and topics they’ve been reading. Over time, Artifact plans to let users adjust which topics they want to see more and less of, or even block publishers.</p>
<p>They’ll also later be able to socialize through comment threads around the stories themselves, in what could be a stealth competitor to Twitter — an app that’s seen a small exodus in the wake of Elon Musk’s takeover. (In fact, Artifact just <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2023/02/22/instagrams-co-founders-personalized-news-app-artifact-launches-to-the-public-with-new-features/" rev="en_rl_none">added a feature similar to Twitter’s</a> with its ability to show you articles trending in your network, if you sync your contacts to the service.)</p>
<div class="embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch">
<blockquote class="wp-embedded-content" data-secret="d8pU7oNtgo"><p><a href="https://techcrunch.com/2023/02/22/instagrams-co-founders-personalized-news-app-artifact-launches-to-the-public-with-new-features/">Instagram’s co-founders’ personalized news app Artifact launches to the public with new features</a></p></blockquote>
<p></div>
<p>As for Artifact’s future, Systrom says he hopes it will eventually become a place where users can go, first and foremost, to discover content around their interests and be able to discuss them with others.</p>
<p>That said, it’s still immeasurably hard for a new consumer app to gain traction without fueling customer acquisition costs <a href="https://mobiledevmemo.com/tiktoks-billion-dollar-secret-that-wasnt/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">with buckets of money</a>. But one thing the team learned from building Instagram, is that Facebook can be a useful tool for gaining adoption. Many of its first users found the app by way of Instagram photos posted to Facebook.</p>
<p>“It turns out that Artifact is actually very similar,” Systrom says. “People discover articles and they want to share them elsewhere…You can share an article from Artifact and it has our branding and it has our domain and URL. It works fairly well for top-of-mind awareness.”</p>
<p>He’s not all that worried that this would have him wading into Facebook’s territory, which to some represents an unbeatable giant.</p>
<p>“I might be a contrarian here, but I think the window has always been open [for new social experiences]. The question is whether or not people choose to attack it and if the right people choose to attack it. I could have never predicted that Snapchat would have risen during Instagram, which obviously had a stronghold on images and social — there was no way to predict there was an opening there. There’s no way to predict that TikTok would have come about when Snap and Instagram were so big. I think these things are far more random than you think.”</p>
<p>These changes tend to be around fundamental changes in technology, like the interest graph, Systrom says.</p>
<p>But, he adds, “I do think we see this wave of machine learning right now that opens up an enormous window to do new things in social.”</p>

Week in Apps: Apple ‘sherlocks’ journaling apps, Twitter’s checkmark apocalypse, Snap summit recap"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Welcome back to This Week in Apps, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/this-week-in-apps\/\">the weekly TechCrunch series<\/a> that recaps the latest in mobile OS news, mobile applications and the overall app economy.<\/p>\n<p>The app economy in 2023 hit a few snags, as consumer spending last year dropped for the first time by 2% <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/11\/the-app-economy-slowed-for-the-first-time-in-2022-with-consumer-spend-down-2-to-167-billion\/\">to $167 billion<\/a>, according to data.ai’s “State of Mobile” report. However, downloads are continuing to grow, up 11% year-over-year in 2022, to reach 255 billion. Consumers are also spending more time in mobile apps than ever before. On Android devices alone, hours spent in 2022 grew 9%, reaching 4.1 trillion.<\/p>\n<p>This Week in Apps offers a way to keep up with this fast-moving industry in one place with the latest from the world of apps, including news, updates, startup fundings, mergers and acquisitions, and much more.<\/p>\n<p><em><strong>Do you want This Week in Apps in your inbox every Saturday? Sign up here: <a href=\"http:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters\">techcrunch.com\/newsletters<\/a><\/strong><\/em><\/p>\n<h1>Top Stories<\/h1>\n<h3>Apple plans its next “sherlock:” journaling apps<\/h3>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--twitter\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">My hope is this brings millions more into journaling, and those who are serious about it will upgrade to a serious paid tool like Day One. <a href=\"https:\/\/t.co\/yJe867frze\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">https:\/\/t.co\/yJe867frze<\/a><\/p>\n<p>— Matt Mullenweg (@photomatt) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/photomatt\/status\/1649416766743891980?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">April 21, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<p>Apple is planning to “sherlock” a new class of applications if a new <a href=\"https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/apple-plans-iphone-journaling-app-in-expansion-of-health-initiatives-690b2c8b?mod=tech_lead_pos1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">report from The Wall Street Journal<\/a> holds true. The paper reported Apple is planning to introduce an iPhone journaling application as part of its expansion of health initiatives. The new app, which is unnamed, would challenge those on the market like Day One (<a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/06\/14\/wordpress-com-owner-automattic-acquires-journaling-app-day-one\/\">acquired by<\/a> WordPress.com maker Automattic in 2021). The WSJ said a document describing Apple’s app noted journaling helps to improve mental and physical well-being.<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>The app is reportedly set to arrive with the launch of iOS 17 and would put Apple again in the crosshairs of regulatory scrutiny. The company has come under fire in recent years for its habit of lifting ideas from the wider app developer and partner community. The practice has become so common, it’s got its own name — sherlocking — a reference to Apple software that started this trend decades ago.<\/p>\n<p>The timing of this move is worth noting. Apple is currently under DoJ <a href=\"https:\/\/www.cnbc.com\/2023\/02\/15\/doj-accelerates-apple-antitrust-investigation-report.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">investigation<\/a> for alleged anticompetitive behavior in the App Store and in other business practices. The DoJ has spoken to companies who have been “sherlocking” victims as part of its inquiry, including Tile, whose business was hit by the launch of Apple’s AirTag. The Justice Dept. has also spoken to other app developers, including smaller companies like <a href=\"https:\/\/www.bloomberg.com\/news\/articles\/2020-06-26\/apple-s-app-store-rules-scrutinized-in-u-s-antitrust-probe?sref=gni836kR\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Basecamp<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/article\/us-tech-antitrust-apple-exclusive\/exclusive-iphone-app-makers-questioned-in-u-s-antitrust-probe-of-apple-sources-idUSKBN1ZY29M\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">parent control software maker Mobicip<\/a>, as well as bigger developers like Match and Spotify, about Apple’s App Store terms.<\/p>\n<p>For Apple to now launch <em>yet another<\/em> app that competes with a number of third-party developers shows Apple is not worried much about the regulatory pressure and isn’t adjusting its behavior.<\/p>\n<p>Related to this, The WSJ also recently ran a feature on<a href=\"https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/apple-watch-patents-5b52cda0?mod=tech_lead_pos6\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> Apple’s “kiss of death,<\/a>” citing partners who detailed what it felt like when the tech giant came calling. After initially being excited by the prospect of an Apple partnership, many partners now say Apple has stolen their ideas for itself, hurting their own businesses.<\/p>\n<h3>Twitter’s Checkmark Apocalypse has arrived — and it’s quite the debacle<\/h3>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2531834\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2531834\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2531834\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/twitter-legacy-verified-removed.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"twitter-legacy-verified-removed\" width=\"680\" height=\"383\" https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/twitter-legacy-verified-removed.jpg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2531834\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Bryce Durbin \/ TechCrunch<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Twitter has finally made good on its promise to <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/twitters-legacy-blue-checkmark-era-is-officially-over\/\">yank its users’ verification checkmarks<\/a> from their profiles in what has to be one of the more ridiculous decisions Elon Musk has made to date since taking ownership of the social media platform.<\/p>\n<p>Seemingly not understanding the value of the company he owns, Musk believes that no one should be verified unless they’re paying Twitter. But in reality, the verification service was a resource provided to Twitter’s community that added value. The blue checkmark symbol indicated that a high-profile figure, celebrity, institution or journalist was who they said they were and not an impersonator.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"EkMbyFbkNQ\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/twitters-legacy-blue-checkmark-era-is-officially-over\/\">Twitter’s legacy blue check mark era is officially over<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Twitter’s legacy blue check mark era is officially over” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/twitters-legacy-blue-checkmark-era-is-officially-over\/embed\/#?secret=9ihZMJgukr#?secret=EkMbyFbkNQ\" data-secret=\"EkMbyFbkNQ\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Twitter is not a curated, visual platform like Instagram, where a verification mark (which you can also <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/03\/17\/meta-launches-paid-verification-on-instagram-and-facebook-in-the-us\/\">now pay for<\/a>!) provides an influencer with clout or bragging rights. Instead, Twitter is a network that’s centered around the rapid-fire dissemination of news and information in real time. The checkmark meant the source had been already vetted to be the real person, organization or official in question, allowing for faster fact-checks. This aids in newsgathering and establishes a baseline of trust across the platform.<\/p>\n<p>But of course, Musk doesn’t understand this.<\/p>\n<p>He has such a low opinion and value for journalism that he went around adding “state-affiliated media” and then “government-funded” labels to the profiles of news outlets like <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/13\/twitter-npr-pbs-leave-elon-musk\/\">PBS<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/05\/twitter-singles-npr-out-with-misleading-state-backed-media-label\/\">NPR<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/17\/twitter-adds-more-government-funded-labels-to-global-news-outlets\/\">CBC, BBC and others<\/a>, lumping these editorially independent news-gathering organizations alongside state-run media entities like the Kremlin-backed Russia Today. Some of the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/13\/twitter-npr-pbs-leave-elon-musk\/\">news organizations<\/a> <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/15\/this-week-in-apps-newsrooms-leave-twitter-reels-expands-android-14-arrives\/\">finally left Twitter<\/a> — something more should do, in fact. (No, I don’t control TC’s social media efforts.)<\/p>\n<p>It’s unclear what’s happening with those labels now, as they’re <a href=\"https:\/\/www.reuters.com\/technology\/twitter-removes-state-affiliated-media-tags-some-accounts-2023-04-21\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">disappearing<\/a> from accounts on Friday, including those of China state-affiliated media.<\/p>\n<p>Musk historically has demonstrated a callous disregard for journalism, calling The NYT “fake,” while <a href=\"https:\/\/apnews.com\/article\/2022-midterm-elections-elon-musk-technology-misinformation-nancy-pelosi-42c1a39e8df739065abd70c400240d84\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">tweeting<\/a> out <em>actual<\/em> fake news himself. He also has Twitter’s comms email <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/elonmusk\/status\/1586871691686223872\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">respond<\/a> to press inquiries with a poop emoji. For that reason, it’s almost funny to watch Musk run headfirst into a wall with his complete mishandling of such a pivotal Twitter feature.<\/p>\n<p>After all, if Musk had wanted to generate revenue from Twitter power users, he could have done so by giving ID-verified users their <em>own<\/em> checkmarks, perhaps with a different color scheme, that provided the set of special features and timeline prioritization that Twitter is now selling with its Blue subscription. That would have added value without disrupting the existing system.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"fHdi5Jx263\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/chaos-reigns-after-twitters-blue-checks-vanish\/\">Chaos reigns after Twitter’s blue checks vanish<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Chaos reigns after Twitter’s blue checks vanish” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/chaos-reigns-after-twitters-blue-checks-vanish\/embed\/#?secret=t26k9jEKND#?secret=fHdi5Jx263\" data-secret=\"fHdi5Jx263\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>Instead, he’s again created chaos by removing checkmarks from almost everyone, allowing for <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/Carnage4Life\/status\/1649212353534369792\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">impersonation<\/a> — and, in some cases, the spread of dangerous <a href=\"https:\/\/www.vice.com\/en\/article\/93kyj5\/twitter-blue-fake-account-sudan-misinformation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">misinformation<\/a>, as well. On top of that, he left legacy checkmarks on some high-profile accounts, like <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/chaos-reigns-after-twitters-blue-checks-vanish\/\">LeBron James and Stephen King<\/a>, both of who said they would not pay for Twitter Blue. It was a power play, clearly. If the celebs don’t leave, they’re tacitly confirming they’ve accepted the new system.<\/p>\n<p>In addition, Twitter is being dishonest about who is truly a paid Twitter Blue subscriber.<\/p>\n<p><em>Yours truly<\/em> paid for Blue earlier this year to fact-check a story and then immediately canceled. I now <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/sarahintampa\/status\/1649140722136674308\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">continue<\/a> to have a checkmark despite the subscription’s expiration in February, as documented below. (In any event, don’t bother to follow me on Twitter, by the way — I’m on <a href=\"https:\/\/bsky.app\/profile\/sarahp.bsky.social\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Bluesky<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/t2.social\/sarahp\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">T2<\/a>, <a href=\"https:\/\/post.news\/@\/sarahp\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Post<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/mastodon.social\/@Sarahp\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Mastodon<\/a>.)<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--twitter\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">I briefly paid for Blue earlier this year to check something out I needed to confirm. I immediately canceled. The subscription expired on Feb. 18, 2023. Yet Twitter would like you to believe that I am a continued Blue subscriber. That's not true. <a href=\"https:\/\/t.co\/N6eXQRY3Pr\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pic.twitter.com\/N6eXQRY3Pr<\/a><\/p>\n<p>— Sarah Perez – please use Signal not DMs (@sarahintampa) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/sarahintampa\/status\/1649140722136674308?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">April 20, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<p>Along with the checkmark removals, Twitter has also now begun <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/21\/twitter-seemingly-now-requires-all-advertisers-to-have-a-verified-checkmark\/\">pressuring advertisers to either pay for Twitter Blue or Verified Organizations<\/a> to continue running ads on the platform. Those businesses that already spend over $1,000 per month will have gold checks automatically, Twitter said.<\/p>\n<h3><strong>Snap’s Partner Summit focuses on Shopping, AR and AI<\/strong><\/h3>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2530985\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2530985\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Snap<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Snap this week hosted its <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/snap-partner-summit-2023\/\">Partner Summit<\/a> where it shared a number of features, updates and initiatives in areas like e-commerce, AR and AI. The company also used the time to introduce a range of consumer-facing updates for its Snapchat mobile app.<\/p>\n<p>At the event, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/19\/snap-ceo-evan-spiegel-tiktok-ban\/\">CEO Evan Spiegel commented<\/a> on the proposed TikTok ban in the U.S., joking at first that Snap would “love that,” but noting that such a ban sets a dangerous precedent for other social platforms. Though he acknowledged there could be national security concerns, the exec, like Zuckerberg has, also pushed for tech regulations.<\/p>\n<p>\u201cIt is important for us to be thoughtful and really develop a regulatory framework to deal with security concerns, especially around technology,\u201d Spiegel.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"NRtvrmCiq0\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/19\/snap-ceo-evan-spiegel-tiktok-ban\/\">Snap CEO Evan Spiegel on TikTok ban: ‘We’d love that’<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Snap CEO Evan Spiegel on TikTok ban: ‘We’d love that’” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/19\/snap-ceo-evan-spiegel-tiktok-ban\/embed\/#?secret=HwMmu2N4KA#?secret=NRtvrmCiq0\" data-secret=\"NRtvrmCiq0\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p><strong>Among the other event highlights and news:<\/strong><\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Snap said the Snapchat+ paid subscription now has <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/19\/snapchat-subscription-now-has-more-than-3-million-users\/\">over 3 million users<\/a><\/strong>. That’s up from 2 million in February and 1 million last August.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Snap <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/19\/snapchat-revenue-share-public-stories\/\">opened<\/a> its Public Story revenue share program to creators<\/strong> with at least 50,000 followers and 25,000 monthly Snap views who post at least 10x per month.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2530501\" A new \u201cPopular Last Night\u201d tag will also show people where their friends were hanging out.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Snapchat is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/19\/snapchat-unveils-new-story-modes-updates-to-snap-map-enhanced-bitmoji-and-more\/\">adding<\/a> an interactive Lens that lets users complete puzzles and play games together while they\u2019re face-to-face on a video call.<\/strong><\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2530353\" style=\"width: 610px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2530353\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2530353\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/08_Calling-Lenses_S03.gif?w=600\" alt=\"Snapchat's calling Lens\" width=\"600\" height=\"343\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2530353\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Snapchat<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Snap also <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/19\/snapchat-launches-ar-lenses-powered-by-generative-ai-starting-with-a-new-cosmic-lens\/\">announced<\/a> new AR Lenses powered by generative AI,<\/strong> starting with a new \u201cCosmic Lens\u201d that turns you and your surroundings into an immersive, animated sci-fi scene. The move follows TikTok’s recently successful launch of the AI filter, “Bold Glamour.” The app will also use AI to recommend Lenses based on the photo or video users provided.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2530385\" style=\"width: 395px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2530385\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"vertical size-large wp-image-2530385\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/SPS-Lens-2.gif?w=385\" alt=\"Snapchat's new AI lens\" width=\"385\" height=\"680\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2530385\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Snapchat<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Bitmoji’s avatar style is being <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/19\/snapchat-unveils-new-story-modes-updates-to-snap-map-enhanced-bitmoji-and-more\/\">updated<\/a> with a more expressive look with realistic dimensions,<\/strong> shading and lighting.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Snap’s enterprise biz, ARES, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/19\/snapchats-ar-technology-comes-to-the-real-world-with-ar-mirrors\/\">introduced<\/a> AR Mirrors<\/strong> — a way to bring AR experiences to real-world locations, like retail stores. class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Snap<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<h1>Platform News<\/h1>\n<h3>Apple<\/h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Apple is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/apples-newest-feature-helps-solve-app-store-billing-issues-without-bugging-developers\/\">introducing a new feature<\/a> that will reduce the burden on app developers when it comes to solving subscription billing issues.<\/strong> Often, when an app\u2019s subscribers have a payment method that fails, they\u2019ll turn to the app developer for help. The app’s chat folders can now be shared with a link, the company says, allowing users to invite friends or colleagues to dozens of work groups, collections of news channels and more.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Google Fi, the tech giant’s carrier service, is being rebranded to Google Fi Wireless and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/google-fi-gets-a-rebrand-expanded-smartwatch-support-new-free-trial-option-and-more\/\">gaining new features,<\/a> including the ability to add on a Pixel Watch or Samsung Galaxy Watch to their plan at no extra charge<\/strong>. The options are available from the Google Fi mobile app and website, where consumers manage their service.<\/li>\n<li><strong>The company behind the popular iPhone customization app Brass and others <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/17\/superchats-new-ai-chatbot-lets-you-message-historical-and-fictional-characters-via-chatgpt\/\">launched<\/a> an AI chat app called Superchat,<\/strong> which allows iOS users to chat with virtual characters powered by OpenAI\u2019s ChatGPT. The gaming platform maker’s 17-to-24 age group has grown 33% year-over-year<\/strong> as kids are aging up but remaining on the platform.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Netflix is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/19\/oxenfree-ii-lost-signals-will-launch-on-netflix-and-other-platforms-on-july-12\/\">launching<\/a> a follow-up to the supernatural thriller Oxenfree after <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2021\/09\/28\/netflix-acquires-its-first-games-studio-oxenfree-developer-night-school\/\">acquiring<\/a> the studio behind the game (Night School Studio) in 2021<\/strong>. <strong>The company says Oxenfree II: Lost Signals will arrive on July 12<\/strong> on Netflix, Nintendo Switch, PS4\/PS5 and Steam. She will replace Pinterest\u2019s current senior vice president of product, Naveen Gavini.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Imgur <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/imgur-will-ban-explicit-images-on-its-platform-this-month\/\">plans to ban explicit images<\/a>, while still allowing for artistic nudity starting on May 15<\/strong>. The MediaLab-owned company said explicit content was a risk to Imgur\u2019s \u201ccommunity and its business,” as the reason for the move.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h3>Streaming and Entertainment<\/h3>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2530817\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2530817\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2530817\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/spotify-bereal.png?w=680\" alt=\"Spotify and Bereal integration\" width=\"680\" height=\"489\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/spotify-bereal.png 2056w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/spotify-bereal.png?resize=150,108 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/spotify-bereal.png?resize=300,216 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/spotify-bereal.png?resize=768,552 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/spotify-bereal.png?resize=680,489 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/spotify-bereal.png?resize=1536,1104 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/spotify-bereal.png?resize=2048,1472 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/spotify-bereal.png?resize=1200,863 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/spotify-bereal.png?resize=50,36 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2530817\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Spotify<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Spotify announced it will now work with BeReal to allow the social app’s users to share what they’re listening to on Spotify<\/strong> through <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/19\/your-bereal-posts-can-now-include-what-youre-listening-to-on-spotify\/\">a new integration<\/a>. After connecting your accounts, BeReal will automatically pull in the song or podcast you\u2019re listening to on Spotify at the time you capture a BeReal.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Creator company Jellysmack is <a href=\"https:\/\/www.tubefilter.com\/2023\/04\/19\/jellysmack-deal-spotify-creators-vin-wiki-christina-randall\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">partnering<\/a> with Spotify to bring its creators to the streaming platform. <\/strong>A selection of its creators will upload weekly video podcast episodes to the service, including Ed Bolian (<a href=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/channel\/UCefl-5pmhZmljwZTE2KrcdA\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">VINwiki<\/a>), <a href=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/@AuditTheAudit\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Audit the Audit<\/a>,\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/channel\/UCZTyzoGspuRurWtbWLEGqLQ\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Christina Randall<\/a>,\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/@BrookeMakenna\/about\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Brooke Makenna<\/a>, and\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/c\/JessicaKent\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Jessica Kent<\/a>.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Cameo <a href=\"https:\/\/cameoblog.medium.com\/introducing-cameo-collage-36a5ef0a80b1?source=rss-ef37ffe85cee------2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">introduced<\/a> Cameo Collage, a free group-gifting feature<\/strong>. Gift givers can now combine celebrity Cameo videos with more personalized videos, images, GIFS and written messages from friends and family to create a digital collage for the recipient.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Netflix in its Q1 earnings said it would <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/18\/netflix-will-crack-down-on-password-sharing-this-summer\/\">begin its password-sharing crackdown<\/a> in the U.S. and other countries this summer<\/strong> (Q2). It has already implemented the changes in Canada, New Zealand, Portugal and Spain.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Netflix reported <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/18\/netflix-will-crack-down-on-password-sharing-this-summer\/\">mixed earnings<\/a><\/strong> with revenue of $8.16 billion, behind estimates of $8.18 billion. It reported higher-than-expected earnings of $2.88 per share in Q1, as analysts had anticipated $2.86 per share.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h3>Transportation<\/h3>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2532259\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2532259\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2532259\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Waze_Parking_MPH_16x9_tighter_cr.width-1000.format-webp.webp?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"382\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Waze_Parking_MPH_16x9_tighter_cr.width-1000.format-webp.webp 1000w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Waze_Parking_MPH_16x9_tighter_cr.width-1000.format-webp.webp?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Waze_Parking_MPH_16x9_tighter_cr.width-1000.format-webp.webp?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Waze_Parking_MPH_16x9_tighter_cr.width-1000.format-webp.webp?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Waze_Parking_MPH_16x9_tighter_cr.width-1000.format-webp.webp?resize=680,382 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Waze_Parking_MPH_16x9_tighter_cr.width-1000.format-webp.webp?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2532259\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Google \/ Waze<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Waze on Google built-in <a href=\"https:\/\/blog.google\/waze\/waze-on-google-built-in-arrives-to-volvo-cars-and-polestar-cars\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">has come to<\/a> Volvo Cars and Polestar 2 cars.<\/strong> After a one-time setup, Volvo and Polestar drivers can access Waze\u2019s real-time routing, navigation, alerts, settings, preferences and saved places on a bigger, eye-level display.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h3>Health & Fitness<\/h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Marvel <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/18\/marvels-new-fitness-app-marvel-move-brings-superheroes-to-your-workout-routine\/\">announced<\/a> a new mobile fitness app, Marvel Move<\/strong>, featuring immersive audio-based running routines with popular Marvel Comics characters. The app, part of a collaboration with Six to Start, co-creator of the popular fitness app Zombies, Run!, includes five storylines to choose from including Thor & Loki, X-Men, The Hulk, Daredevil and Doctor Strange and the Scarlet Witch.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p><img decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"aligncenter size-large wp-image-2532303\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/marvel-move-app.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"680\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/marvel-move-app.jpg 1080w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/marvel-move-app.jpg?resize=150,150 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/marvel-move-app.jpg?resize=300,300 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/marvel-move-app.jpg?resize=768,768 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/marvel-move-app.jpg?resize=680,680 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/marvel-move-app.jpg?resize=32,32 32w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/marvel-move-app.jpg?resize=50,50 50w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/marvel-move-app.jpg?resize=64,64 64w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/marvel-move-app.jpg?resize=96,96 96w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/marvel-move-app.jpg?resize=128,128 128w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><\/p>\n<h3>News<\/h3>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Samsung <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/18\/samsungs-news-app-launches-with-custom-feeds-and-daily-briefings\/\">launched<\/a> its own take on Apple News with its new \u201cSamsung News\u201d app<\/strong> that gives users access to everyday news from a variety of publications. The app will replace the company\u2019s current \u201cSamsung Free\u201d app, and includes custom news feeds in addition to morning and evening briefings about the top news of the day.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h1>Government, Policy and Lawsuits<\/h1>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>WhatsApp, Signal, Viber, Wire and other encrypted messaging apps signed <a href=\"https:\/\/blog.whatsapp.com\/an-open-letter\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">an open letter<\/a> asking the U.K. government to “urgently rethink” its Online Safety Bill legislation, <\/strong>which they say will force tech companies to <strong>break end-to-end encryption <\/strong>on private messaging services, weakening the “privacy of billions of people around the world.”<\/li>\n<li><strong>Google <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/google-asks-court-to-dismiss-multiple-claims-in-epic-games-antitrust-trial\/\">has asked the court to dismiss multiple claims<\/a> in its antitrust trial with Epic Games, Match, state AGs and others.<\/strong> In a new filing, Google\u2019s legal team is now asking the court to dismiss several of the plaintiffs\u2019 arguments regarding the nature of its app store business, revenue-sharing agreements and other app store-related projects in a partial motion for summary judgment. Google believes the court should now have enough information on hand to make determinations on a handful of the plaintiffs\u2019 claims before the case goes to trial, saying that these items are not in violation of antitrust law. If the court agrees with Google\u2019s position, the trial would still move forward as other claims would still need to be argued in court.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"aHsLgbgjJf\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/google-asks-court-to-dismiss-multiple-claims-in-epic-games-antitrust-trial\/\">Google asks court to dismiss multiple claims in Epic Games antitrust trial<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Google asks court to dismiss multiple claims in Epic Games antitrust trial” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/google-asks-court-to-dismiss-multiple-claims-in-epic-games-antitrust-trial\/embed\/#?secret=GlMDdced7s#?secret=aHsLgbgjJf\" data-secret=\"aHsLgbgjJf\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>The U.K. Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/19\/google-play-store-billing-choice-uk\/\">opened a consultation<\/a> on Google’s proposal to let developers use alternative payment methods for in-app purchases on Android, aka “User Choice Billing.<\/strong>” It’s inviting interested stakeholders to respond to Google’s proposal by May 19 and will then make a decision on whether to accept the comments and resolve the case. Google is suggesting it cuts its commission to 4% if the developer offers Google’s own billing alongside their own. But this would only be cut to 3% if just third-party billing was offered.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Montana lawmakers <a href=\"https:\/\/www.wsj.com\/articles\/montana-lawmakers-approve-statewide-ban-on-tiktok-17dc0ea6?mod=djemalertNEWS\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">approved<\/a> a bill that would ban TikTok and would bar app stores from offering the app within the state<\/strong>, starting on January 1, 2024. It’s unclear how such a measure would be enforced as the app stores don’t offer a way to block distribution by state, only by country.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h1>Funding and M&A<\/h1>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Starboard (Formerly Olympic Media) concluded the acquisition of right-wing Twitter alternative Parler and shut it down<\/strong>. The company <a href=\"https:\/\/parler.com\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">said<\/a> of the decision: <em>“No reasonable person believes that a Twitter clone just for conservatives is a viable business any more [sic].”<\/em> The Parler app will undergo a strategic assessment and it’s not clear what the company has in store for its future.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Epic Games expanded its Latin American footprint with its <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/epic-buys-brazil-based-game-developer-aquiris-to-boost-fortnite\/\">acquisition<\/a> of the Brazilian game development studio Aquiris<\/strong>. The developer is best known for “Wonderbox: The Adventure Maker,” a magic-themed game-creation sandbox available on Apple Arcade.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--video embed--youtube\"><iframe class=\"embed-iframe embed-iframe--youtube\" title=\"Aquiris Reel 2022\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" src=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/embed\/QxYDHQHVnKk?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share\" allowfullscreen><\/iframe><\/div>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Myxt, an audio file management platform for creators, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.musicbusinessworldwide.com\/audio-file-management-startup-myxt-founded-by-ex-google-and-stripe-developers-raises-2m\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">raised $2 million<\/a><\/strong> in seed funding led by Accel Ventures and Quiet Capital. The startup offers a collaborative workplace app for audio creators that’s available on web, iOS and Android, where users can stream tracks, organize files and back up their library.<\/li>\n<li><strong>SoundHound closed on <a href=\"http:\/\/voicebot.ai\/2023\/04\/17\/soundhound-raises-100m-in-strategic-financing\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">$100 million<\/a> in strategic funding from Atlas Credit Partners<\/strong> as part of a new $125 million loan facility. The publicly traded company is using the money to refinance its debt and continue to fund its long-term strategy.<\/li>\n<li><strong>Japanese gaming giant Sega is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/17\/sega-to-acquire-angry-birds-maker-rovio-for-775m\/\">acquiring<\/a> Finland\u2019s Rovio in an all-cash deal worth \u20ac706 million ($775 million).<\/strong> The deal is expected to close in Q2 or Rovio’s fiscal year (in the next couple of months). Sega\u2019s offer represents a 63.1% premium on Rovio\u2019s closing price on January 19.<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<h1>Downloads<\/h1>\n<h3>Wavelength<\/h3>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2531466\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2531466\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2531466\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/PlatformsFill.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"Wavelength group chat\" width=\"680\" height=\"407\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/PlatformsFill.jpg 3810w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/PlatformsFill.jpg?resize=150,90 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/PlatformsFill.jpg?resize=300,180 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/PlatformsFill.jpg?resize=768,460 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/PlatformsFill.jpg?resize=680,407 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/PlatformsFill.jpg?resize=1536,919 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/PlatformsFill.jpg?resize=2048,1226 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/PlatformsFill.jpg?resize=1200,718 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/PlatformsFill.jpg?resize=50,30 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2531466\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Wavelength<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>An interesting new chat app called Wavelength has arisen out of the ashes of the social networking app <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/10\/11\/hands-on-with-telepath-the-social-network-taking-aim-at-abuse-fake-news-and-to-some-extent-free-speech\/\">Telepath<\/a>, which shut down last year. Now the team has shifted its focus to improving group chat experiences. Instead of having different group chats, it introduces the idea of threaded messaging combined with AI. The threads help to keep group chats less cluttered by making it easier to follow multiple conversations at once.<\/p>\n<p>In addition, users can add OpenAI’s GPT-3.5 into their group chats by mentioning @AI. This makes the app among the first to offer chatting with AI. Snapchat is also <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/19\/snapchat-opens-its-ai-chatbot-to-global-users-says-the-ai-will-later-snap-you-back\/\">now doing this with its My AI feature<\/a> as is <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/03\/15\/ghost-debuts-an-anonymous-group-messaging-app-with-chatgpt-baked-in\/\">Ghost, which allows groups to chat with ChatGPT.<\/a><\/p>\n<p>The startup aims to focus in other areas as well, like privacy, moderation, discovery and more. Notably, <a href=\"https:\/\/daringfireball.net\/2023\/03\/wavelength\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">John Gruber<\/a> is an advisor for the currently iOS and Mac-only app.<\/p>\n<p>You can read more about Wavelength <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/wavelength-is-a-new-app-trying-to-make-group-chat-suck-less\/\">here<\/a>.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"mqmKLx4qaX\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/wavelength-is-a-new-app-trying-to-make-group-chat-suck-less\/\">Wavelength is a new app trying to make group chat suck less<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Wavelength is a new app trying to make group chat suck less” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/wavelength-is-a-new-app-trying-to-make-group-chat-suck-less\/embed\/#?secret=emaIZLxpGk#?secret=mqmKLx4qaX\" data-secret=\"mqmKLx4qaX\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<h3>Nocam<\/h3>\n<p>A new social video app called <a href=\"https:\/\/apps.apple.com\/us\/app\/nocam\/id6444664861\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Nocam<\/a> has a radical idea to make social networking more authentic \u2014 it\u2019s turning off the camera so you can\u2019t see how you look while filming. The idea is to make capturing a moment feel natural while reducing the friction that comes with seeing a preview of your own image, which can often leave users hesitant to post or scrambling to add edits and filters to touch up their appearance.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2531685\" style=\"width: 378px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2531685\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"vertical size-large wp-image-2531685\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/phone-record.png?w=368\" alt=\"\" width=\"368\" height=\"680\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/phone-record.png 848w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/phone-record.png?resize=81,150 81w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/phone-record.png?resize=162,300 162w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/phone-record.png?resize=768,1420 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/phone-record.png?resize=368,680 368w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/phone-record.png?resize=831,1536 831w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/phone-record.png?resize=649,1200 649w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/phone-record.png?resize=27,50 27w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 368px) 100vw, 368px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2531685\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Nocam<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Nocam\u00a0believes this concept better reflects the way people interact in real life, where we\u00a0aren\u2019t faced by a mirror that shows us what we look like, that is. The company describes its app as BeReal meets TikTok. But perhaps it’s more accurate to say BeReal meets TikTok Challenges, as the app focuses on sending users fun or silly prompts they have to act out with the camera, like doing a dance or just showing what they’re up to. Users can also prompt their friends, too.<\/p>\n<p>You can read more about Nocam <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/nocam-unveils-a-social-video-app-thats-like-bereal-meets-tiktok-challenges\/\">here<\/a>.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"EUb3LGs7BG\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/nocam-unveils-a-social-video-app-thats-like-bereal-meets-tiktok-challenges\/\">Nocam unveils a social video app that’s like BeReal meets TikTok challenges<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Nocam unveils a social video app that’s like BeReal meets TikTok challenges” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/04\/20\/nocam-unveils-a-social-video-app-thats-like-bereal-meets-tiktok-challenges\/embed\/#?secret=pra9hs2PCU#?secret=EUb3LGs7BG\" data-secret=\"EUb3LGs7BG\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<h3>Proton Pass<\/h3>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2530745\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2530745\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2530745\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Proton-Pass-1.jpeg?w=680\" alt=\"A screenshot of the browser extension of Proton Pass\" width=\"680\" height=\"383\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Proton-Pass-1.jpeg 2000w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Proton-Pass-1.jpeg?resize=150,84 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Proton-Pass-1.jpeg?resize=300,169 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Proton-Pass-1.jpeg?resize=768,432 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Proton-Pass-1.jpeg?resize=680,383 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Proton-Pass-1.jpeg?resize=1536,865 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Proton-Pass-1.jpeg?resize=1200,676 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Proton-Pass-1.jpeg?resize=50,28 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2530745\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Proton<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Proton, the maker of the end-to-end encrypted email service Proton Mail, Proton VPN, Proton Drive and Proton Calendar, this week launched a new password manager called Proton Pass. Everything stored in the app is end-to-end encrypted, and Proton itself never has access to your data. stand-your-audience\/","title":{"rendered":"Read the room"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\"><em>W<\/em><br \/>\n<em>elcome to the TechCrunch Exchange, a weekly startups-and-markets newsletter. It\u2019s inspired by the <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/the-exchange\/?utm_source=internal&utm_medium=WPunit\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">daily TechCrunch+ column<\/a> where it gets its name. Want it in your inbox every Saturday? Sign up <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/newsletters?utm_source=internal&utm_medium=WPunit\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">here<\/a>.<\/em><\/p>\n<p><span class=\"featured__span-first-words\">This week, I look<\/span> into cybersecurity sales, developer content marketing, and fundraising pitches through a common lens: The importance of understanding your audience and putting it first. \u2014 <\/i><a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/abracarioca\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><i>Anna<\/i><\/a><\/p>\n<h2>Bridging the gap between cybersecurity vendors and buyers<\/h2>\n<p>Budget cuts brought on by the economic downturn have caused a shift in the priorities and mindsets of chief information security officers (CISOs). As security practitioners start reporting to corporate boards, they need to understand how to do so and be more business-focused than technical-focused, says marketing expert <a href=\"https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/in\/daniarad\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Dani Woolf<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>Woolf knows CISOs well; having spent her career in B2B tech marketing, she spent months interviewing cybersecurity buyers for her <a href=\"https:\/\/www.audience1st.fm\/podcast\/episodes\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">podcast<\/a> before launching her own audience research agency, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.audience1st.fm\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Audience 1st<\/a>, to help vendors get better at understanding their target.<\/p>\n<p>A key challenge at the moment is for cybersecurity vendors to adapt to the buyers’ new mindset \u2014 which Woolf thinks will remain even after the market recovers. “There’s this huge gap right now in that vendors are adding more complexity to the security buyer job, and they don’t understand that simplicity is the goal.”<\/p>\n<p>Simplicity, however, doesn’t mean pitching one tool to replace them all. One of the main things that buyers want to hear from a vendor, Woolf told me, is how well are you integrating with their existing tech stack. “Because as a buyer, I can’t rip out what I have right now.”<\/p>\n<h2>Understanding CISOs<\/h2>\n<p><div class=\"extra-crunch-offer-container\"><\/div>","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Let’s look into cybersecurity sales, developer content
