all contribute to AI — should we get paid for that?"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">In Silicon Valley, some of the brightest minds believe a universal basic income (UBI) that guarantees people unrestricted cash payments will help them to survive and thrive as advanced technologies eliminate more careers as we know them, from white collar and creative jobs — lawyers, journalists, artists, software engineers — to <a href=\"https:\/\/venturebeat.com\/ai\/how-john-deere-grew-data-seeds-into-an-ai-powerhouse\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">labor roles<\/a>. The idea has gained enough traction that <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2022\/09\/10\/business\/economy\/guaranteed-income.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">dozens<\/a> of guaranteed income programs have been started in U.S. cities since 2020.<\/p>\n<p>Yet even Sam Altman, the CEO of OpenAI and one of the highest-profile <a href=\"https:\/\/www.cnbc.com\/2017\/09\/06\/silicon-valley-exec-on-cash-handouts-eliminate-poverty-for-americans.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">proponents<\/a> of UBI, doesn’t believe that it’s a complete solution. As he said during a <a href=\"https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/watch?v=ebjkD1Om4uw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">sit-down<\/a> earlier this year, “I think it is a little part of the solution. I think it’s great. I think as [advanced artificial intelligence] participates more and more in the economy, we should distribute wealth and resources much more than we have and that will be important over time. But I don’t think that’s going to solve the problem. I don’t think that’s going to give people meaning, I don’t think it means people are going to entirely stop trying to create and do new things and whatever else. So I would consider it an enabling technology, but not a plan for society.”<\/p>\n<p>The question begged is what a plan for society should then look like, and computer scientist Jaron Lanier, a founder in the field of virtual reality, writes in this week’s <a href=\"https:\/\/www.newyorker.com\/science\/annals-of-artificial-intelligence\/there-is-no-ai\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">New Yorker<\/a> that “data dignity” could be an even bigger part of the solution.<\/p>\n<p>Here’s the basic premise: Right now, we mostly give our data for free in exchange for free services. Lanier argues that in the age of AI, we need to stop doing this, that the powerful models currently working their way into society need instead to “be connected with the humans” who give them so much to ingest and learn from in the first place.<\/p>\n<p>The idea is for people to “get paid for what they create, even when it is filtered and recombined” into something that’s unrecognizable.<\/p>\n<p>The concept isn’t brand new, with Lanier first introducing the notion of data dignity in a 2018 Harvard Business Review piece titled, \u201c<a href=\"https:\/\/hbr.org\/2018\/09\/a-blueprint-for-a-better-digital-society\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">A Blueprint for a Better Digital Society<\/a>.\u201d<\/p>\n<p>As he wrote at the time with co-author and economist Glen Weyl, \u201c[R]hetoric from the tech sector suggests a coming wave of underemployment due to artificial intelligence (AI) and automation.” But the predictions of UBI advocates “leave room for only two outcomes,” and they’re extreme, Lanier and Weyl observed. “Either there will be mass poverty despite technological advances, or much wealth will have to be taken under central, national control through a social wealth fund to provide citizens a universal basic income.”<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>The problem is that both “hyper-concentrate power and undermine or ignore the value of data creators,” they wrote.<\/p>\n<h2>Untangle my mind<\/h2>\n<p>Of course, assigning people the right amount of credit for their countless contributions to everything that exists online is not a minor challenge. Lanier acknowledges that even data-dignity researchers can’t agree on how to disentangle everything that AI models have absorbed or how detailed an accounting should be attempted. Still, Lanier thinks that it could be done — gradually.<\/p>\n<p>Alas, even if there is a will, a more immediate challenge — lack of access — is a lot to overcome. Though OpenAI had released some of its training data in previous years, it has since closed the kimono completely, citing competitive and safety concerns. When OpenAI President Greg Brockman <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/03\/15\/interview-with-openais-greg-brockman-gpt-4-isnt-perfect-but-neither-are-you\/\">described to TechCrunch last month<\/a> the training data for OpenAI’s latest and most powerful large language model, GPT-4, he said it derived from a “variety of licensed, created, and publicly available data sources, which may include publicly available personal information,” but he declined to offer anything more specific.<\/p>\n<p>Unsurprisingly, regulators are grappling with what to do. OpenAI — whose technology in particular is spreading like wildfire — is already in the crosshairs of a growing number of countries, including the Italian authority, which has blocked the use of its popular ChatGPT chatbot. French, German, Irish, and Canadian data regulators are also investigating how it collects and uses data.<\/p>\n<p>Margaret Mitchell, an AI researcher who was formerly Google\u2019s AI ethics co-lead, tells the outlet\u00a0<a href=\"https:\/\/www.technologyreview.com\/2023\/04\/19\/1071789\/openais-hunger-for-data-is-coming-back-to-bite-it\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> Technology Review<\/a>, that it might be nearly impossible at this point for all these companies to identify individuals\u2019 data and remove it from their models.<\/p>\n<p>As explained by the outlet: OpenAI would be better off today if it had built in data record-keeping from the start, but it’s standard in the AI industry to build data sets for AI models by scraping the web indiscriminately and then outsourcing some of the clean-up of that data.<\/p>\n<h2>How to save a life<\/h2>\n<p>If these players have a limited understanding of what’s now in their models, that’s a daunting challenge to the “data dignity” proposal of Lanier.<\/p>\n<p>Whether it renders it impossible is something only time will tell.<\/p>\n<p>Certainly, there is merit in determining <em>some<\/em> way to give people ownership over their work, even if that work is made outwardly “other” by the time a large language model has chewed through it.<\/p>\n<p>It’s also highly likely that frustration over who owns what will grow as more of the world is reshaped by these new tools. Already, OpenAI and others are facing <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2023\/1\/16\/23557098\/generative-ai-art-copyright-legal-lawsuit-stable-diffusion-midjourney-deviantart\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">numerous<\/a> and wide-ranging <a href=\"https:\/\/www.theverge.com\/2023\/1\/28\/23575919\/microsoft-openai-github-dismiss-copilot-ai-copyright-lawsuit\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">copyright infringement lawsuits<\/a> over whether or not they have the right to scrape the entire internet to feed their algorithms.<\/p>\n<p>Either way, it’s not just about giving credit where it’s due; recognizing people’s contribution to AI systems may be necessary to preserve humans’ sanity over time, suggests Lanier in his New Yorker piece.<\/p>\n<p>He believes that people need agency, and as he sees it, universal basic income “amounts to putting everyone on the dole in order to preserve the idea of black-box artificial intelligence.”<\/p>\n<p>Meanwhile, ending the “black box nature of our current AI models” would make an accounting of people’s contributions easier — which would make them more inclined to stay engaged and continue making contributions.<\/p>\n<p>It might all boil down to establishing a new creative class instead of a new dependent class, he writes. And which would you prefer to be a part of?<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>In Silicon Valley, some of the brightest minds believe a universal basic income (UBI) that guarantees people unrestricted cash payments will help them to survive and thrive as advanced technologies eliminate more careers as we know them, from white collar and creative jobs — lawyers, journalists, artists, software engineers — to labor roles. style=\"font-weight: 400;\">launched<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> an online form for \u201cTransgender Center Concerns\u201d in late March, inviting those who\u2019ve witnessed \u201ctroubling practices\u201d at clinics that provide gender-affirming care to submit tips. The site didn\u2019t ask users to name patients or healthcare providers, but encouraged users to complete the form \u201cin as much detail as possible.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2532495\" style=\"width: 1084px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2532495\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2532495 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Screenshot-2023-04-21-at-11.06.05-AM-1.png\" alt=\"The form asked users to submit complaints and concerns about gender-affirming care.\" width=\"1074\" height=\"1148\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Screenshot-2023-04-21-at-11.06.05-AM-1.png 1074w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Screenshot-2023-04-21-at-11.06.05-AM-1.png?resize=140,150 140w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Screenshot-2023-04-21-at-11.06.05-AM-1.png?resize=281,300 281w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Screenshot-2023-04-21-at-11.06.05-AM-1.png?resize=768,821 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Screenshot-2023-04-21-at-11.06.05-AM-1.png?resize=636,680 636w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/04\/Screenshot-2023-04-21-at-11.06.05-AM-1.png?resize=47,50 47w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1074px) 100vw, 1074px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2532495\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Before the form was taken down, people spammed it with raunchy fanfiction and rambling anecdotes. <strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> <span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Missouri Attorney General (s<\/span>creenshot)<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">But after days of <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/tiktok\/\">TikTok<\/a> and <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/tag\/twitter\/\">Twitter<\/a> users spamming the site with gibberish, the tip line has been removed from the Missouri government site entirely. Instead of the online form, the link to the tip line now says that the page no longer exists.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Madeline Sieren, press secretary for Missouri Attorney General Andrew Bailey, blamed \u201cfar left activists\u201d for breaking the site. She said the tip line is down temporarily.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cRather than standing on their supposed science to back up their facts, they\u2019re resorting to trying to hack our system to silence victims of the exact network we\u2019re attempting to expose,\u201d Sieren told TechCrunch in an email. \u201cIn order to ensure the integrity of a government website, the page is temporarily down while we investigate these matters.\u201d\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Sieren did not clarify what the \u201chack\u201d entailed.\u00a0<\/span><\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Bailey said his office set up the tip line for parents to submit concerns about the gender-affirming care their children received from transgender youth centers. He also issued an emergency rule severely restricting access to gender-affirming care.\u00a0\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><a href=\"https:\/\/promoonline.org\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">PROMO<\/a>, a Missouri LGBTQ advocacy organization, said Bailey \u201cfanned the flames of hate\u201d in issuing the emergency rule.\u00a0<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">\u201cThe Attorney General’s claims are maliciously cherry-picked and come from unverified sources that allow him to promulgate disgusting, obstructive, and misleading information into an emergency rule,\u201d PROMO said in a <\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/_imPRessive_\/status\/1646631888428171265\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">statement<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">. \u201cIt should be clear to anyone paying attention that the real threat to Missourians is the attorney general himself.\u201d<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Social media users on TikTok, Twitter and Tumblr ensured that Bailey\u2019s office would have plenty of evidence to sift through for the investigation, flooding the site with fake complaints and other ephemera.<\/span><\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">When the online form first launched, it lacked a CAPTCHA, which savvy Twitter users quickly used to their advantage by<\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/itshotchange\/status\/1648290698985127936\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> <span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">using bots to spam the site<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">. Users also employed a<\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/JacoNext\/status\/1649128864717631504\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> <span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">generator<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> to churn out fake names and fake Missouri addresses. Others just dumped text into the complaint form, ranging from the<\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/www.tiktok.com\/@softscorpio\/video\/7223232828329266478\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> <span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">entire script of the “Bee Movie,”<\/span><\/a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"> to<\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/QuarkySpaceCat\/status\/1648158692104183808\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> <span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Billy May’s OxiClean sales pitch,<\/span><\/a> <span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">to<\/span><a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/notthediz\/status\/1648532229772148740\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"> <span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Walter White’s introductory monologue in “Breaking is Auto-GPT and why does it matter?"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Silicon Valley’s quest to automate everything is unceasing, which explains its latest obsession: <a href=\"https:\/\/github.com\/Significant-Gravitas\/Auto-GPT\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Auto-GPT<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>In essence, Auto-GPT uses the versatility of OpenAI’s latest AI models to interact with software and services online, allowing it to “autonomously” perform tasks like X and Y. But as we are learning with large language models, this capability seems to be as wide as an ocean but as deep as a puddle.<\/p>\n<p>Auto-GPT — which you might’ve seen blowing up on social media recently — is an open source app created by game developer Toran Bruce Richards <span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">that uses OpenAI’s text-generating models, mainly GPT-3.5 and GPT-4, to act “autonomously.”<br \/>\n<\/span><\/p>\n<p>There’s no magic in that autonomy. Auto-GPT simply handles follow-ups to an initial prompt of OpenAI’s models, both asking and answering them until a task is complete.<\/p>\n<p>Auto-GPT, basically, is GPT-3.5 and GPT-4 paired with a companion bot that instructs GPT-3.5 and GPT-4 what to do. A user tells Auto-GPT what their goal is and the bot, in turn, uses GPT-3.5 and GPT-4 and several programs to carry out every step needed to achieve whatever goal they’ve set.<\/p>\n<p><span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">What makes Auto-GPT reasonably capable is its ability to interact with apps, software and services both online and local, like web browsers and word processors. For example, given a prompt like “help me grow my flower business,” Auto-GPT can<\/span> develop a somewhat plausible advertising strategy and build a basic website.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--twitter\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\"><a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/hashtag\/AutoGPT?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">#AutoGPT<\/a> is the new disruptive kid on the block- It can apply <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/hashtag\/ChatGPT?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">#ChatGPT<\/a>'s reasoning to broader, more intricate issues requiring planning & multiple steps. <\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>Still early but very impressive with many health and biomedicine applications. <\/p>\n<p>Just tried <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/hashtag\/AgentGPT?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">#AgentGPT<\/a> and asked it to\u2026 <a href=\"https:\/\/t.co\/ywFhtjxjYD\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pic.twitter.com\/ywFhtjxjYD<\/a><\/p>\n<p>— Daniel Kraft, MD (@daniel_kraft) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/daniel_kraft\/status\/1646015825797861379?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">April 12, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<p>As Joe Koen, a software developer who’s experimented with Auto-GPT, explained to TechCrunch via email, Auto-GPT essentially automates multi-step projects that would’ve required back-and-forth prompting with a chatbot-oriented AI model like, say, OpenAI’s ChatGPT.<\/p>\n<p>“Auto-GPT defines an agent that communicates with OpenAI’s API,” Koen said. “<span style=\"font-size: 1rem; letter-spacing: -0.1px;\">This agent’s objective is to carry out a variety of commands that the AI generates in response to the agent’s requests. <\/span>The user is prompted for input to specify the AI’s role and objectives prior to the agent starting to carry out commands.”<\/p>\n<p>In a terminal, users describe the Auto-GPT agent’s name, role and objective and specify up to five ways to achieve that objective. For example:<\/p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Name: <\/strong>Smartphone-GPT<\/li>\n<li><strong>Role: <\/strong>An AI designed to find the best smartphone<\/li>\n<li><strong>Objective: <\/strong>Find the best smartphones on the market<\/li>\n<li><strong>Goal 1: <\/strong>Do market research for different smartphones on the market today<\/li>\n<li><strong>Goal 2: <\/strong>Get the top five smartphones and list their pros and cons<\/li>\n<\/ul>\n<p>Behind the scenes, Auto-GPT relies on features like memory management to execute tasks, along with GPT-4 and GPT-3.5 for text generation, file storage and summarization.<\/p>\n<p>Auto-GPT can also be hooked up to speech synthesizers, like <a href=\"https:\/\/beta.elevenlabs.io\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">ElevenLabs’<\/a>, so that it can “place” phone calls, for example.<\/p>\n<p>Auto-GPT is publicly available on GitHub, but it does require some setup and know-how to get up and running. To use it, Auto-GPT has to be installed in a development environment like Docker, and it must be registered with an API key from OpenAI — which requires a paid OpenAI account.<\/p>\n<p>It might be worth it — although the jury’s out on that. Early adopters have used Auto-GPT to take on the sorts of mundane tasks better delegated to a bot. For example, Auto-GPT can field items like debugging code and writing an email or more advanced things, like creating a business plan for a new startup.<\/p>\n<p>“If Auto-GPT encounters any obstacles or inability to finish the task, it’ll develop new prompts to help it navigate the situation and determine the appropriate next steps,” Adnan Masood, the chief architect at UST, a tech consultancy firm, told TechCrunch in an email. “Large language models excel at generating human-like responses, yet rely on user prompts and interactions to deliver desired outcomes. In contrast, Auto-GPT leverages the advanced capabilities of OpenAI’s API to operate independently without user intervention.”<\/p>\n<p>In recent weeks, new apps have emerged to make Auto-GPT even easier to use, like <a href=\"https:\/\/agentgpt.reworkd.ai\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">AgentGPT<\/a> and GodMode, which provide a simple interface where users can input what they want to accomplish directly on a browser page. Note that, like Agent-GPT, both require an API key from OpenAI to unlock their full capabilities.<\/p>\n<p>Like any powerful tool, however, Auto-GPT has its limitations — and risks.<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--twitter\">\n<blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet\" data-width=\"550\" data-dnt=\"true\">\n<p lang=\"en\" dir=\"ltr\">AutoGPT just exceeded PyTorch itself in GitHub stars (74k vs 65k). I see AutoGPT as a fun experiment, as the authors point out too. But nothing more. Prototypes are not meant to be production-ready. Don't let media fool you – most of the "cool demos" are heavily cherry-picked: \ud83e\uddf5 <a href=\"https:\/\/t.co\/I44H7BkCqr\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">pic.twitter.com\/I44H7BkCqr<\/a><\/p>\n<p>— Jim Fan (@DrJimFan) <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/DrJimFan\/status\/1647616587199815684?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">April 16, 2023<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><script async src=\"https:\/\/platform.twitter.com\/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"><\/script><\/div>\n<p>Depending on what objective the tool’s provided, Auto-GPT can behave in very… unexpected ways. One Reddit <a href=\"https:\/\/www.reddit.com\/r\/OpenAI\/comments\/12lzpwy\/using_torantulinoautogpt_from_github_ive_given\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">user<\/a> claims that, given a budget of $100 to spend within a server instance, Auto-GPT made a wiki page on cats, exploited a flaw in the instance to gain admin-level access and took over the Python environment in which it was running — and then “killed” itself.<\/p>\n<p>There’s also ChaosGPT, a modified version of Auto-GPT tasked with goals like “destroy humanity” and “establish global dominance.” Unsurprisingly, ChaosGPT hasn’t come close to bringing about the robot apocalypse — but it has <a href=\"https:\/\/www.foxnews.com\/tech\/ai-bot-chaosgpt-plans-destroy-humanity-we-must-eliminate-them\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">tweeted<\/a> rather unflatteringly about humankind.<\/p>\n<p>Arguably more dangerous than Auto-GPT attempting to “destroy humanity” are the unanticipated problems that can crop up in otherwise perfectly normal scenarios, though. Because it’s built on OpenAI’s language models — models that, like all language models, are prone to inaccuracies — it can make errors.<\/p>\n<p>That’s not the only problem. After successfully completing a task, Auto-GPT usually doesn’t recall how to perform it for later use, and — even when it does — it often won’t remember to use the program. Auto-GPT also struggles to effectively break complex tasks into simpler sub-tasks and has trouble understanding how different goals overlap.<\/p>\n<p>“Auto-GPT illustrates the power and unknown risks of generative AI,” Clara Shih, the CEO of Salesforce’s Service Cloud and an Auto-GPT enthusiast, said via email. “For enterprises, it is especially important to include a human in the loop approach when developing and using generative AI technologies like Auto-GPT.”<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Silicon Valley’s quest to automate everything is unceasing, which explains its latest obsession: Auto-GPT. In essence, Auto-GPT uses the versatility of OpenAI’s latest AI models to interact with software and services online, allowing it to “autonomously” perform tasks like X and Y. But as we are learning with large language models, this capability seems to tech behind Artifact, the newly launched news aggregator from Instagram’s co-founders"},"content":{"rendered":"<p id=\"speakable-summary\">Late last month, <a href=\"https:\/\/artifact.news\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Artifact<\/a>, a <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/01\/31\/instagrams-co-founders-introduce-a-new-social-app-for-news-reading\/\">personalized news reader <\/a>built by Instagram\u2019s co-founders, <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/22\/instagrams-co-founders-personalized-news-app-artifact-launches-to-the-public-with-new-features\/\">opened<\/a> to the public. The launch was a surprise to many consumers, who wondered why the team behind one of the world’s most iconic social apps would return to startups to focus on one of the toughest areas instead: news. It’s an ecosystem where publishers are failing left and right and misinformation is rampant, as the founders surely saw themselves while working at Facebook.<\/p>\n<p>In an interview, Instagram co-founder Kevin Systrom explains what drew him to this space and how his new app’s underlying technology will serve to differentiate it from the competition.<\/p>\n<p>The startup’s existence, in some ways, can be credited to the COVID pandemic, as that’s what brought the Instagram co-founders, Systrom and Mike Krieger, back together. During the early days of the pandemic in 2020, the co-founders teamed up for the first time since leaving Facebook to create <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/04\/18\/instagram-founders-rt-live\/\">a COVID-19 dashboard called Rt.live<\/a> that tracked the spread of the virus across the U.S.<\/p>\n<p>But in later months, other COVID trackers emerged and people were no longer as interested in tracking the virus’s spread on a state-by-state basis. Invigorated by the experience, the founders began then to think about returning to work on a “real company” instead of a public good side project.<\/p>\n<h3>Machine learning is the “future of social”<\/h3>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2197512\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2197512\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2197512\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?w=680\" alt=\"AI - artificial intelligence CPU concept. Machine learning. CPU on the board with glow tracks. Background scientific concept in blue light, 3D illustration\" width=\"680\" height=\"453\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg 2121w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=1536,1024 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=2048,1365 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=1200,800 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2021\/09\/GettyImages-1136663830.jpg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2197512\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Usis \/ Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Deciding on their next act took time. The founders hacked around on stuff for a year and a half or so after their initial collaboration, Systrom says. The founder, who describes himself as a “very frameworks-driven person,” knew he wanted to do something that involved machine learning, having seen its power at Instagram.<\/p>\n<p>“It was super fascinating to me to work on it at Instagram and watch it go from a company without machine learning to a company driven by machine learning,” he says. “I also witnessed the rise of TikTok and realized how important machine learning would be for the future of social.”<\/p><div class=\"piano-inline-promo\"><\/div>\n<p>He himself observed how social networking’s underlying graph had changed a lot over the years, watching as Facebook invented what’s now known as the “friend graph” — a user’s personal social network of real-life connections. Later, he saw Twitter pioneer the “follow graph,” or a graph of connections based on the user’s explicit choices of who they want to follow on a service. Then, at Instagram, Systrom saw firsthand the shift from the “follow graph” to the “inferred graph” or, rather, the “interest graph.”<\/p>\n<p>This, he explains, was basically a “follow graph” powered by machine learning, instead of by users clicking a button.<\/p>\n<p>The potential to leverage machine learning and an interest graph within a new product appealed to him, he says.<\/p>\n<p>“We looked for an area that was social in nature, but where we could apply 20% new techniques — and that would be the machine learning side of what we’re doing,” Systrom says, describing how the founders narrowed their focus.<\/p>\n<h3>Fixing a broken news ecosystem<\/h3>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2495453\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2495453\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2495453\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?w=680\" alt=\"\" width=\"680\" height=\"453\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg 6000w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=1536,1024 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=2048,1365 2048w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=1200,800 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/newspaper-stack_GettyImages648942926.jpeg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2495453\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> <a href=\"https:\/\/www.gettyimages.com\/search\/photographer?photographer=jayk7\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">jayk7 <span class=\"screen-reader-text\">(opens in a new window)<\/span><\/a> \/ Getty Images<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>The other consideration that prompted the founders’ interest in news, more specifically, was the potential impact if the app succeeded. They wanted to work on a startup they felt the world needed, Systrom says. No doubt, some of that interest may have been fueled by working at Facebook (now Meta), which had changed consumers’ news consumption behavior, impacting publishers as well as the spread of misinformation.<\/p>\n<p>“It felt like our consumption of information — both factual, balanced, entertaining, etc. — had an existential crisis,” Systrom tells TechCrunch. Plus, he adds, “many of the people producing this content are going out of business.”<\/p>\n<p>Meanwhile, on the consumer side of the news reading experience, there’s so much information swirling around that people don’t know what they can trust or which item to read. People are asking themselves if a link shared by a friend is actually legit and they’re wondering why they’re reading one article over the many others published on the same topic.<\/p>\n<p>“It might be cheesy to say, because I’ve now said it a bunch of times, but I feel like the worst part about social media is that it’s social,” Systrom says. “I think the ‘social’ part of social media — for a long time, in terms of information consumption — has been a hack to filter for information that would be interesting to you. But we now don’t need that hack, because we can learn what’s interesting to you,” he continues. “We can quantify it. We can build profiles. And then we can serve you content that is both high-quality, balanced and interesting to you.”<\/p>\n<p>This realization led to the creation of Artifact, a social news app powered by machine learning.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2489439\" style=\"width: 1960px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2489439\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"wp-image-2489439 size-full\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/artifact.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1950\" height=\"1398\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/artifact.jpg 1950w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/artifact.jpg?resize=150,108 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/artifact.jpg?resize=300,215 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/artifact.jpg?resize=768,551 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/artifact.jpg?resize=680,488 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/artifact.jpg?resize=1536,1101 1536w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/artifact.jpg?resize=1200,860 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/02\/artifact.jpg?resize=50,36 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1950px) 100vw, 1950px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2489439\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Artifact personalization and stats<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>The app in some ways is very much like others that exist today, which have been founded in other countries, including ByteDance’s <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2018\/11\/17\/jinri-toutiao-new-ceo\/\">Toutiao<\/a> in China, Japan’s <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/09\/17\/smartnews-u-s-app-unveils-new-features-for-the-elections-covid-19-and-local-weather\/\">SmartNews<\/a> and News Break, another personalized news reader <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2020\/05\/27\/meet-news-break-the-news-app-trending-in-america-founded-by-a-chinese-media-veteran\/\">with Chinese roots<\/a>. Like its rivals, Artifact learns from user behavior, engagement and other factors in order to personalize which headlines are presented and in which order.<\/p>\n<p>Despite this competitive landscape, Systrom believes U.S. news consumers want an option that’s actually based in their home market.<\/p>\n<p>“They want a domestic player with a team they trust,” Systrom says, speaking to the news aggregation landscape in the U.S.<\/p>\n<p>His comment is a timely one, given how tensions in the U.S. have been growing over China’s grip on the social networking market with TikTok. The short video app, which is often used as a source for news by Gen Z, is now banned on government phones and <a href=\"https:\/\/www.nytimes.com\/2023\/03\/06\/technology\/white-house-congress-on-tiktok.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">bipartisan legislation to further police it is in the works<\/a>.<\/p>\n<h3>Clearing out the clickbait<\/h3>\n<p>In addition to its locale, Systrom believes Artifact will be able to differentiate itself based on its unique combination of technology and taste — a directive that could also be used to describe Instagram’s founding for that matter.<\/p>\n<p>Unlike Facebook — which became a platform by which any publisher could deliver news, and oftentimes clickbait — Artifact’s news sources are curated up front, the founder explains.<\/p>\n<p>“When I say taste, I mean the top of the funnel in our system — the publishers we choose to distribute,” notes Systrom. “It’s not a free-for-all. We don’t crawl the entire web and just let everything go in.”<\/p>\n<p>Instead, Artifact has selected the top publishers across different categories to fuel the content in the app. Customers can add their own paid subscriptions, as well. At this time, Artifact doesn’t sell those for a revenue share or involve itself in publishers’ ad sales, though one day that could change, depending on how the app chooses to monetize.<\/p>\n<p>For now, however, the focus is on gaining traction with consumers and ensuring the app’s news sources are worth reading.<\/p>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2494033\" style=\"width: 324px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2494033\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"vertical wp-image-2494033 size-large\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/IMG_5041.png?w=314\" alt=\"\" width=\"314\" height=\"680\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/IMG_5041.png 1290w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/IMG_5041.png?resize=69,150 69w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/IMG_5041.png?resize=138,300 138w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/IMG_5041.png?resize=768,1665 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/IMG_5041.png?resize=314,680 314w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/IMG_5041.png?resize=709,1536 709w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/IMG_5041.png?resize=945,2048 945w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/IMG_5041.png?resize=554,1200 554w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/03\/IMG_5041.png?resize=23,50 23w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 314px) 100vw, 314px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2494033\" class=\"wp-caption-text\">Screenshot of Artifact app. <strong>Image Source:<\/strong> Artifact<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>“The line, internally…is we want a balanced ideological corpus, subject to integrity and quality,” Systrom says. “And the idea is not that we only choose left-wing, or we only choose right-wing. We drew the line at quality and integrity subject to a bunch of the metrics that a lot of these third-party fact-checking services have. The third-party services basically rate the integrity of different publishers based on their research and based on public events — like how quickly they correct their stories, whether their funding is transparent, all that kind of stuff,” he notes.<\/p>\n<p>“You can claim it’s editorial,” he continues. “But it’s more about making sure that the set that we’re going to distribute and pour into this powerful machine — that can distribute content widely — that we’re being responsible by giving it content that isn’t going to be misinformation.”<\/p>\n<p>Beyond the integrity of reporting, Artifact aims to deliver a news experience that’s more fulfilling.<\/p>\n<p>“If you log on to a lot of these other sources, you get pretty clickbaity-stuff,” Systrom points out. “I’m not trying to throw shade on folks working in this area, but we wouldn’t work on it if we thought that it was solved. We focus a lot in our system on a different objective, which is this idea of value…if we put in the top-quality sources in these categories and we have coverage — whether it’s parenting or mental wellness, or exercise — that we can create a differentiated content set that feels much different than the front page of a major newspaper but also feels very different than a lot of the other aggregators,” he says.<\/p>\n<p>Yet, even as the app personalizes its content selection to the end user, it doesn’t leave them in so-called “filter bubbles,” necessarily, as Facebook did. Instead, when users click on a headline to read a story, they’re shown the entire coverage across sources, allowing them to peruse the story from different vantage points.<\/p>\n<h3>Artifact’s recommendation system<\/h3>\n<p><div id=\"attachment_2477785\" style=\"width: 690px\" class=\"wp-caption aligncenter\"><img aria-describedby=\"caption-attachment-2477785\" decoding=\"async\" loading=\"lazy\" class=\"size-large wp-image-2477785\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/01\/Product_Shot.jpeg?w=680\" alt=\"Artifact displayed on smartphone laid on colored tiles\/blocks\" width=\"680\" height=\"453\" srcset=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/01\/Product_Shot.jpeg 1200w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/01\/Product_Shot.jpeg?resize=150,100 150w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/01\/Product_Shot.jpeg?resize=300,200 300w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/01\/Product_Shot.jpeg?resize=768,512 768w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/01\/Product_Shot.jpeg?resize=680,453 680w, https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2023\/01\/Product_Shot.jpeg?resize=50,33 50w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 680px) 100vw, 680px\" \/><p id=\"caption-attachment-2477785\" class=\"wp-caption-text\"><strong>Image Credits:<\/strong> Artifact<\/p><\/div><\/p>\n<p>Systrom credits Toutiao for driving innovation in recommendation systems, noting that Toutiao essentially helped ByteDance give birth to TikTok. The technology developed for its news discovery was brought to its acquisition of Musical.ly, which became the Chinese app Douyin and its international counterpart TikTok.<\/p>\n<p>But Systrom believes some of the machine learning that Artificat is doing is different.<\/p>\n<p>“The machine learning that a lot of what we’re doing is based on was invented in 2017 at Google. It’s called the transformer…without that, GPT 3, 3.5 etc., wouldn’t exist. Without that, you wouldn’t have DALL-E. Without that, you wouldn’t have ChatGPT,” he says. “You’re inventing a core technology that can then be applied in many different ways.”<\/p>\n<p>The app’s algorithms are focused on more than just tracking clicks and engagement. It weighs other factors, too, like dwell time, read time, shares, stories that get shared in DMs (private messages) and more.<\/p>\n<p>“If you let your algorithm focus on clicks, it will end up serving clickbait. If you simply optimize for only what people have clicked on, you end up having tunnel vision,” Systrom explains.<\/p>\n<p>The model additionally involves an algorithm called <a href=\"https:\/\/medium.com\/analytics-vidhya\/the-epsilon-greedy-algorithm-for-reinforcement-learning-5fe6f96dc870\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Epsilon-Greedy<\/a>.<\/p>\n<p>“That’s a technical term for you taking some small portion of your time — like 10% or 20% — and you explore. You do something different than you would normally do…you go to the outside of the recommendation spectrum rather than the core of it,” Systrom says. “It’s shown many, many times, especially in reinforcement learning, that having this ‘explore’ budget we’ll call it, actually is optimal for users.”<\/p>\n<p>That’s the same reason why TikTok <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/02\/tiktok-introduces-a-strike-system-for-violations-tests-a-feature-to-refresh-the-for-you-feed\/#:~:text=With%20the%20new%20refresh%20button,to%20their%20For%20You%20feed.\">has begun testing tools that let users refresh their feeds<\/a>. Without the added spice of unexpected content, the video app’s suggestions had grown stale for some users.<\/p>\n<p>But because the news changes every day, Artifact’s use of this Epsilon-Greedy algorithm also has to adapt as users’ own interests in topics grow and wane. For example, someone might be very into reading about the upcoming elections up until Election Day has passed. Or a new story may immediately capture their attention when it comes out of nowhere, as the story about the Chinese spy balloon did.<\/p>\n<p>Artifact’s editorial consideration, if you can call it that, will also come into how the app’s algorithm is programmed, not just its publisher selections.<\/p>\n<p>“Actually, building the algorithm is enormously editorial,” Systrom says. “Because what you choose to train your algorithm on — the objective function, the data you put in, the data you include, the data you don’t include — is all in editorial judgment. The way you weight different objectives.”<\/p>\n<p>“All of the edge a company has is in its ability to wrangle the data in such a way that produces an outcome that’s optimal,” Systrom says.<\/p>\n<p>If anything is Artifact’s secret sauce, it’s that.<\/p>\n<h3>Does Artifact have a future?<\/h3>\n<p>Whether all this tech and “taste” is enough for Artifact to succeed remains to be seen. The U.S. news aggregation landscape is not like China’s. And here, Artifact will have to fight against the default ways people access news, including through the news apps that come bundled with their smartphones, as well as the large internet portals like Google and Facebook, and some extent, YouTube and TikTok too.<\/p>\n<p>At launch, Artifact added new functionality, including a new feature that allows users to track how they’ve been engaging with the app and its content in a metrics section, which shows a list of publishers and topics they’ve been reading. Over time, Artifact plans to let users adjust which topics they want to see more and less of, or even block publishers.<\/p>\n<p>They’ll also later be able to socialize through comment threads around the stories themselves, in what could be a stealth competitor to Twitter — an app that’s seen a small exodus in the wake of Elon Musk’s takeover. (In fact, Artifact just <a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/22\/instagrams-co-founders-personalized-news-app-artifact-launches-to-the-public-with-new-features\/\" rev=\"en_rl_none\">added a feature similar to Twitter’s<\/a> with its ability to show you articles trending in your network, if you sync your contacts to the service.)<\/p>\n<div class=\"embed breakout embed-oembed embed--techcrunch\">\n<blockquote class=\"wp-embedded-content\" data-secret=\"d8pU7oNtgo\"><p><a href=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/22\/instagrams-co-founders-personalized-news-app-artifact-launches-to-the-public-with-new-features\/\">Instagram’s co-founders’ personalized news app Artifact launches to the public with new features<\/a><\/p><\/blockquote>\n<p><iframe class=\"wp-embedded-content\" sandbox=\"allow-scripts\" security=\"restricted\" style=\"position: absolute; clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);\" title=\"“Instagram’s co-founders’ personalized news app Artifact launches to the public with new features” — TechCrunch\" src=\"https:\/\/techcrunch.com\/2023\/02\/22\/instagrams-co-founders-personalized-news-app-artifact-launches-to-the-public-with-new-features\/embed\/#?secret=bg7R3kPNEj#?secret=d8pU7oNtgo\" data-secret=\"d8pU7oNtgo\" width=\"800\" height=\"450\" frameborder=\"0\" marginwidth=\"0\" marginheight=\"0\" scrolling=\"no\"><\/iframe><\/div>\n<p>As for Artifact’s future, Systrom says he hopes it will eventually become a place where users can go, first and foremost, to discover content around their interests and be able to discuss them with others.<\/p>\n<p>That said, it’s still immeasurably hard for a new consumer app to gain traction without fueling customer acquisition costs <a href=\"https:\/\/mobiledevmemo.com\/tiktoks-billion-dollar-secret-that-wasnt\/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">with buckets of money<\/a>. But one thing the team learned from building Instagram, is that Facebook can be a useful tool for gaining adoption. Many of its first users found the app by way of Instagram photos posted to Facebook.<\/p>\n<p>“It turns out that Artifact is actually very similar,” Systrom says. “People discover articles and they want to share them elsewhere…You can share an article from Artifact and it has our branding and it has our domain and URL. It works fairly well for top-of-mind awareness.”<\/p>\n<p>He’s not all that worried that this would have him wading into Facebook’s territory, which to some represents an unbeatable giant.<\/p>\n<p>“I might be a contrarian here, but I think the window has always been open [for new social experiences]. The question is whether or not people choose to attack it and if the right people choose to attack it. I could have never predicted that Snapchat would have risen during Instagram, which obviously had a stronghold on images and social — there was no way to predict there was an opening there. There’s no way to predict that TikTok would have come about when Snap and Instagram were so big. I think these things are far more random than you think.”<\/p>\n<p>These changes tend to be around fundamental changes in technology, like the interest graph, Systrom says.<\/p>\n<p>But, he adds, “I do think we see this wave of machine learning right now that opens up an enormous window to do new things in social.”<\/p>\n","protected":false},"excerpt":{"rendered":"<p>Late last month, Artifact, a personalized news reader built by Instagram\u2019s co-founders, opened to the public. The launch was a surprise to many consumers, who wondered why the team behind one of the world’s most iconic social apps would return to startups to focus on one of the toughest areas instead: news. It’s an ecosystem readabilityObject.title: The tech behind Artifact, the newly launched news aggregator from Instagram's co-founders
readabilityObject.content:
Late last month, Artifact, a personalized news reader built by Instagramâ€™s co-founders, opened to the public. The launch was a surprise to many consumers, who wondered why the team behind one of the worldâ€™s most iconic social apps would return to startups to focus on one of the toughest areas instead: news. Itâ€™s an ecosystem where publishers are failing left and right and misinformation is rampant, as the founders surely saw themselves while working at Facebook.

In an interview, Instagram co-founder Kevin Systrom explains what drew him to this space and how his new appâ€™s underlying technology will serve to differentiate it from the competition.

The startupâ€™s existence, in some ways, can be credited to the COVID pandemic, as thatâ€™s what brought the Instagram co-founders, Systrom and Mike Krieger, back together. During the early days of the pandemic in 2020, the co-founders teamed up for the first time since leaving Facebook to create a COVID-19 dashboard called Rt.live that tracked the spread of the virus across the U.S.

But in later months, other COVID trackers emerged and people were no longer as interested in tracking the virusâ€™s spread on a state-by-state basis. Invigorated by the experience, the founders began then to think about returning to work on a â€œreal companyâ€ instead of a public good side project.

Machine learning is the â€œfuture of socialâ€

Image Credits: Usis / Getty Images

Deciding on their next act took time. The founders hacked around on stuff for a year and a half or so after their initial collaboration, Systrom says. The founder, who describes himself as a â€œvery frameworks-driven person,â€ knew he wanted to do something that involved machine learning, having seen its power at Instagram.

â€œIt was super fascinating to me to work on it at Instagram and watch it go from a company without machine learning to a company driven by machine learning,â€ he says. â€œI also witnessed the rise of TikTok and realized how important machine learning would be for the future of social.â€

He himself observed how social networkingâ€™s underlying graph had changed a lot over the years, watching as Facebook invented whatâ€™s now known as the â€œfriend graphâ€ â€” a userâ€™s personal social network of real-life connections. Later, he saw Twitter pioneer the â€œfollow graph,â€ or a graph of connections based on the userâ€™s explicit choices of who they want to follow on a service. Then, at Instagram, Systrom saw firsthand the shift from the â€œfollow graphâ€ to the â€œinferred graphâ€ or, rather, the â€œinterest graph.â€

This, he explains, was basically a â€œfollow graphâ€ powered by machine learning, instead of by users clicking a button.

The potential to leverage machine learning and an interest graph within a new product appealed to him, he says.

â€œWe looked for an area that was social in nature, but where we could apply 20% new techniques â€” and that would be the machine learning side of what weâ€™re doing,â€ Systrom says, describing how the founders narrowed their focus.

Fixing a broken news ecosystem

The other consideration that prompted the foundersâ€™ interest in news, more specifically, was the potential impact if the app succeeded. They wanted to work on a startup they felt the world needed, Systrom says. No doubt, some of that interest may have been fueled by working at Facebook (now Meta), which had changed consumersâ€™ news consumption behavior, impacting publishers as well as the spread of misinformation.

â€œIt felt like our consumption of information â€” both factual, balanced, entertaining, etc. â€” had an existential crisis,â€ Systrom tells TechCrunch. Plus, he adds, â€œmany of the people producing this content are going out of business.â€

Meanwhile, on the consumer side of the news reading experience, thereâ€™s so much information swirling around that people donâ€™t know what they can trust or which item to read. People are asking themselves if a link shared by a friend is actually legit and theyâ€™re wondering why theyâ€™re reading one article over the many others published on the same topic.

â€œIt might be cheesy to say, because Iâ€™ve now said it a bunch of times, but I feel like the worst part about social media is that itâ€™s social,â€ Systrom says. â€œI think the â€˜socialâ€™ part of social media â€” for a long time, in terms of information consumption â€” has been a hack to filter for information that would be interesting to you. But we now donâ€™t need that hack, because we can learn whatâ€™s interesting to you,â€ he continues. â€œWe can quantify it. We can build profiles. And then we can serve you content that is both high-quality, balanced and interesting to you.â€

This realization led to the creation of Artifact, a social news app powered by machine learning.

Image Credits: Artifact personalization and stats

The app in some ways is very much like others that exist today, which have been founded in other countries, including ByteDanceâ€™s Toutiao in China, Japanâ€™s SmartNews and News Break, another personalized news reader with Chinese roots. Like its rivals, Artifact learns from user behavior, engagement and other factors in order to personalize which headlines are presented and in which order.

Despite this competitive landscape, Systrom believes U.S. news consumers want an option thatâ€™s actually based in their home market.

â€œThey want a domestic player with a team they trust,â€ Systrom says, speaking to the news aggregation landscape in the U.S.

His comment is a timely one, given how tensions in the U.S. have been growing over Chinaâ€™s grip on the social networking market with TikTok. The short video app, which is often used as a source for news by Gen Z, is now banned on government phones and bipartisan legislation to further police it is in the works.

Clearing out the clickbait

In addition to its locale, Systrom believes Artifact will be able to differentiate itself based on its unique combination of technology and taste â€” a directive that could also be used to describe Instagramâ€™s founding for that matter.

Unlike Facebook â€” which became a platform by which any publisher could deliver news, and oftentimes clickbait â€” Artifactâ€™s news sources are curated up front, the founder explains.

â€œWhen I say taste, I mean the top of the funnel in our system â€” the publishers we choose to distribute,â€ notes Systrom. â€œItâ€™s not a free-for-all. We donâ€™t crawl the entire web and just let everything go in.â€

Instead, Artifact has selected the top publishers across different categories to fuel the content in the app. Customers can add their own paid subscriptions, as well. At this time, Artifact doesnâ€™t sell those for a revenue share or involve itself in publishersâ€™ ad sales, though one day that could change, depending on how the app chooses to monetize.

For now, however, the focus is on gaining traction with consumers and ensuring the appâ€™s news sources are worth reading.

Screenshot of Artifact app. Image Source: Artifact

â€œThe line, internallyâ€¦is we want a balanced ideological corpus, subject to integrity and quality,â€ Systrom says. â€œAnd the idea is not that we only choose left-wing, or we only choose right-wing. We drew the line at quality and integrity subject to a bunch of the metrics that a lot of these third-party fact-checking services have. The third-party services basically rate the integrity of different publishers based on their research and based on public events â€” like how quickly they correct their stories, whether their funding is transparent, all that kind of stuff,â€ he notes.

â€œYou can claim itâ€™s editorial,â€ he continues. â€œBut itâ€™s more about making sure that the set that weâ€™re going to distribute and pour into this powerful machine â€” that can distribute content widely â€” that weâ€™re being responsible by giving it content that isnâ€™t going to be misinformation.â€

Beyond the integrity of reporting, Artifact aims to deliver a news experience thatâ€™s more fulfilling.

â€œIf you log on to a lot of these other sources, you get pretty clickbaity-stuff,â€ Systrom points out. â€œIâ€™m not trying to throw shade on folks working in this area, but we wouldnâ€™t work on it if we thought that it was solved. We focus a lot in our system on a different objective, which is this idea of valueâ€¦if we put in the top-quality sources in these categories and we have coverage â€” whether itâ€™s parenting or mental wellness, or exercise â€” that we can create a differentiated content set that feels much different than the front page of a major newspaper but also feels very different than a lot of the other aggregators,â€ he says.

Yet, even as the app personalizes its content selection to the end user, it doesnâ€™t leave them in so-called â€œfilter bubbles,â€ necessarily, as Facebook did. Instead, when users click on a headline to read a story, theyâ€™re shown the entire coverage across sources, allowing them to peruse the story from different vantage points.

Artifactâ€™s recommendation system

Image Credits: Artifact

Systrom credits Toutiao for driving innovation in recommendation systems, noting that Toutiao essentially helped ByteDance give birth to TikTok. The technology developed for its news discovery was brought to its acquisition of Musical.ly, which became the Chinese app Douyin and its international counterpart TikTok.

But Systrom believes some of the machine learning that Artificat is doing is different.

â€œThe machine learning that a lot of what weâ€™re doing is based on was invented in 2017 at Google. Itâ€™s called the transformerâ€¦without that, GPT 3, 3.5 etc., wouldnâ€™t exist. Without that, you wouldnâ€™t have DALL-E. Without that, you wouldnâ€™t have ChatGPT,â€ he says. â€œYouâ€™re inventing a core technology that can then be applied in many different ways.â€

The appâ€™s algorithms are focused on more than just tracking clicks and engagement. It weighs other factors, too, like dwell time, read time, shares, stories that get shared in DMs (private messages) and more.

â€œIf you let your algorithm focus on clicks, it will end up serving clickbait. If you simply optimize for only what people have clicked on, you end up having tunnel vision,â€ Systrom explains.

The model additionally involves an algorithm called Epsilon-Greedy.

â€œThatâ€™s a technical term for you taking some small portion of your time â€” like 10% or 20% â€” and you explore. You do something different than you would normally doâ€¦you go to the outside of the recommendation spectrum rather than the core of it,â€ Systrom says. â€œItâ€™s shown many, many times, especially in reinforcement learning, that having this â€˜exploreâ€™ budget weâ€™ll call it, actually is optimal for users.â€

Thatâ€™s the same reason why TikTok has begun testing tools that let users refresh their feeds. Without the added spice of unexpected content, the video appâ€™s suggestions had grown stale for some users.

But because the news changes every day, Artifactâ€™s use of this Epsilon-Greedy algorithm also has to adapt as usersâ€™ own interests in topics grow and wane. For example, someone might be very into reading about the upcoming elections up until Election Day has passed. Or a new story may immediately capture their attention when it comes out of nowhere, as the story about the Chinese spy balloon did.

Artifactâ€™s editorial consideration, if you can call it that, will also come into how the appâ€™s algorithm is programmed, not just its publisher selections.

â€œActually, building the algorithm is enormously editorial,â€ Systrom says. â€œBecause what you choose to train your algorithm on â€” the objective function, the data you put in, the data you include, the data you donâ€™t include â€” is all in editorial judgment. The way you weight different objectives.â€

â€œAll of the edge a company has is in its ability to wrangle the data in such a way that produces an outcome thatâ€™s optimal,â€ Systrom says.

If anything is Artifactâ€™s secret sauce, itâ€™s that.

Does Artifact have a future?

Whether all this tech and â€œtasteâ€ is enough for Artifact to succeed remains to be seen. The U.S. news aggregation landscape is not like Chinaâ€™s. And here, Artifact will have to fight against the default ways people access news, including through the news apps that come bundled with their smartphones, as well as the large internet portals like Google and Facebook, and some extent, YouTube and TikTok too.

At launch, Artifact added new functionality, including a new feature that allows users to track how theyâ€™ve been engaging with the app and its content in a metrics section, which shows a list of publishers and topics theyâ€™ve been reading. Over time, Artifact plans to let users adjust which topics they want to see more and less of, or even block publishers.

Theyâ€™ll also later be able to socialize through comment threads around the stories themselves, in what could be a stealth competitor to Twitter â€” an app thatâ€™s seen a small exodus in the wake of Elon Muskâ€™s takeover. (In fact, Artifact just added a feature similar to Twitterâ€™s with its ability to show you articles trending in your network, if you sync your contacts to the service.)

As for Artifactâ€™s future, Systrom says he hopes it will eventually become a place where users can go, first and foremost, to discover content around their interests and be able to discuss them with others.

That said, itâ€™s still immeasurably hard for a new consumer app to gain traction without fueling customer acquisition costs with buckets of money. But one thing the team learned from building Instagram, is that Facebook can be a useful tool for gaining adoption. Many of its first users found the app by way of Instagram photos posted to Facebook.

â€œIt turns out that Artifact is actually very similar,â€ Systrom says. â€œPeople discover articles and they want to share them elsewhereâ€¦You can share an article from Artifact and it has our branding and it has our domain and URL. It works fairly well for top-of-mind awareness.â€

Heâ€™s not all that worried that this would have him wading into Facebookâ€™s territory, which to some represents an unbeatable giant.

â€œI might be a contrarian here, but I think the window has always been open [for new social experiences]. The question is whether or not people choose to attack it and if the right people choose to attack it. I could have never predicted that Snapchat would have risen during Instagram, which obviously had a stronghold on images and social â€” there was no way to predict there was an opening there. Thereâ€™s no way to predict that TikTok would have come about when Snap and Instagram were so big. I think these things are far more random than you think.â€

These changes tend to be around fundamental changes in technology, like the interest graph, Systrom says.

But, he adds, â€œI do think we see this wave of machine learning right now that opens up an enormous window to do new things in social.â€

Late last month, Artifact, a personalized news reader built by Instagramâ€™s co-founders, opened to the public. The launch was a surprise to many consumers, who wondered why the team behind one of the worldâ€™s most iconic social apps would return to startups to focus on one of the toughest areas instead: news. Itâ€™s an ecosystem where publishers are failing left and right and misinformation is rampant, as the founders surely saw themselves while working at Facebook.
In an interview, Instagram co-founder Kevin Systrom explains what drew him to this space and how his new appâ€™s underlying technology will serve to differentiate it from the competition.
The startupâ€™s existence, in some ways, can be credited to the COVID pandemic, as thatâ€™s what brought the Instagram co-founders, Systrom and Mike Krieger, back together. During the early days of the pandemic in 2020, the co-founders teamed up for the first time since leaving Facebook to create a COVID-19 dashboard called Rt.live that tracked the spread of the virus across the U.S.
But in later months, other COVID trackers emerged and people were no longer as interested in tracking the virusâ€™s spread on a state-by-state basis. Invigorated by the experience, the founders began then to think about returning to work on a â€œreal companyâ€ instead of a public good side project.
Machine learning is the â€œfuture of socialâ€
Image Credits: Usis / Getty Images
Deciding on their next act took time. The founders hacked around on stuff for a year and a half or so after their initial collaboration, Systrom says. The founder, who describes himself as a â€œvery frameworks-driven person,â€ knew he wanted to do something that involved machine learning, having seen its power at Instagram.
â€œIt was super fascinating to me to work on it at Instagram and watch it go from a company without machine learning to a company driven by machine learning,â€ he says. â€œI also witnessed the rise of TikTok and realized how important machine learning would be for the future of social.â€
He himself observed how social networkingâ€™s underlying graph had changed a lot over the years, watching as Facebook invented whatâ€™s now known as the â€œfriend graphâ€ â€” a userâ€™s personal social network of real-life connections. Later, he saw Twitter pioneer the â€œfollow graph,â€ or a graph of connections based on the userâ€™s explicit choices of who they want to follow on a service. Then, at Instagram, Systrom saw firsthand the shift from the â€œfollow graphâ€ to the â€œinferred graphâ€ or, rather, the â€œinterest graph.â€
This, he explains, was basically a â€œfollow graphâ€ powered by machine learning, instead of by users clicking a button.
The potential to leverage machine learning and an interest graph within a new product appealed to him, he says.
â€œWe looked for an area that was social in nature, but where we could apply 20% new techniques â€” and that would be the machine learning side of what weâ€™re doing,â€ Systrom says, describing how the founders narrowed their focus.
Fixing a broken news ecosystem

The other consideration that prompted the foundersâ€™ interest in news, more specifically, was the potential impact if the app succeeded. They wanted to work on a startup they felt the world needed, Systrom says. No doubt, some of that interest may have been fueled by working at Facebook (now Meta), which had changed consumersâ€™ news consumption behavior, impacting publishers as well as the spread of misinformation.
â€œIt felt like our consumption of information â€” both factual, balanced, entertaining, etc. â€” had an existential crisis,â€ Systrom tells TechCrunch. Plus, he adds, â€œmany of the people producing this content are going out of business.â€
Meanwhile, on the consumer side of the news reading experience, thereâ€™s so much information swirling around that people donâ€™t know what they can trust or which item to read. People are asking themselves if a link shared by a friend is actually legit and theyâ€™re wondering why theyâ€™re reading one article over the many others published on the same topic.
â€œIt might be cheesy to say, because Iâ€™ve now said it a bunch of times, but I feel like the worst part about social media is that itâ€™s social,â€ Systrom says. â€œI think the â€˜socialâ€™ part of social media â€” for a long time, in terms of information consumption â€” has been a hack to filter for information that would be interesting to you. But we now donâ€™t need that hack, because we can learn whatâ€™s interesting to you,â€ he continues. â€œWe can quantify it. We can build profiles. And then we can serve you content that is both high-quality, balanced and interesting to you.â€
This realization led to the creation of Artifact, a social news app powered by machine learning.
Image Credits: Artifact personalization and stats
The app in some ways is very much like others that exist today, which have been founded in other countries, including ByteDanceâ€™s Toutiao in China, Japanâ€™s SmartNews and News Break, another personalized news reader with Chinese roots. Like its rivals, Artifact learns from user behavior, engagement and other factors in order to personalize which headlines are presented and in which order.
Despite this competitive landscape, Systrom believes U.S. news consumers want an option thatâ€™s actually based in their home market.
â€œThey want a domestic player with a team they trust,â€ Systrom says, speaking to the news aggregation landscape in the U.S.
His comment is a timely one, given how tensions in the U.S. have been growing over Chinaâ€™s grip on the social networking market with TikTok. The short video app, which is often used as a source for news by Gen Z, is now banned on government phones and bipartisan legislation to further police it is in the works.
Clearing out the clickbait
In addition to its locale, Systrom believes Artifact will be able to differentiate itself based on its unique combination of technology and taste â€” a directive that could also be used to describe Instagramâ€™s founding for that matter.
Unlike Facebook â€” which became a platform by which any publisher could deliver news, and oftentimes clickbait â€” Artifactâ€™s news sources are curated up front, the founder explains.
â€œWhen I say taste, I mean the top of the funnel in our system â€” the publishers we choose to distribute,â€ notes Systrom. â€œItâ€™s not a free-for-all. We donâ€™t crawl the entire web and just let everything go in.â€
Instead, Artifact has selected the top publishers across different categories to fuel the content in the app. Customers can add their own paid subscriptions, as well. At this time, Artifact doesnâ€™t sell those for a revenue share or involve itself in publishersâ€™ ad sales, though one day that could change, depending on how the app chooses to monetize.
For now, however, the focus is on gaining traction with consumers and ensuring the appâ€™s news sources are worth reading.
Screenshot of Artifact app. Image Source: Artifact
â€œThe line, internallyâ€¦is we want a balanced ideological corpus, subject to integrity and quality,â€ Systrom says. â€œAnd the idea is not that we only choose left-wing, or we only choose right-wing. We drew the line at quality and integrity subject to a bunch of the metrics that a lot of these third-party fact-checking services have. The third-party services basically rate the integrity of different publishers based on their research and based on public events â€” like how quickly they correct their stories, whether their funding is transparent, all that kind of stuff,â€ he notes.
â€œYou can claim itâ€™s editorial,â€ he continues. â€œBut itâ€™s more about making sure that the set that weâ€™re going to distribute and pour into this powerful machine â€” that can distribute content widely â€” that weâ€™re being responsible by giving it content that isnâ€™t going to be misinformation.â€
Beyond the integrity of reporting, Artifact aims to deliver a news experience thatâ€™s more fulfilling.
â€œIf you log on to a lot of these other sources, you get pretty clickbaity-stuff,â€ Systrom points out. â€œIâ€™m not trying to throw shade on folks working in this area, but we wouldnâ€™t work on it if we thought that it was solved. We focus a lot in our system on a different objective, which is this idea of valueâ€¦if we put in the top-quality sources in these categories and we have coverage â€” whether itâ€™s parenting or mental wellness, or exercise â€” that we can create a differentiated content set that feels much different than the front page of a major newspaper but also feels very different than a lot of the other aggregators,â€ he says.
Yet, even as the app personalizes its content selection to the end user, it doesnâ€™t leave them in so-called â€œfilter bubbles,â€ necessarily, as Facebook did. Instead, when users click on a headline to read a story, theyâ€™re shown the entire coverage across sources, allowing them to peruse the story from different vantage points.
Artifactâ€™s recommendation system
Image Credits: Artifact
Systrom credits Toutiao for driving innovation in recommendation systems, noting that Toutiao essentially helped ByteDance give birth to TikTok. The technology developed for its news discovery was brought to its acquisition of Musical.ly, which became the Chinese app Douyin and its international counterpart TikTok.
But Systrom believes some of the machine learning that Artificat is doing is different.
â€œThe machine learning that a lot of what weâ€™re doing is based on was invented in 2017 at Google. Itâ€™s called the transformerâ€¦without that, GPT 3, 3.5 etc., wouldnâ€™t exist. Without that, you wouldnâ€™t have DALL-E. Without that, you wouldnâ€™t have ChatGPT,â€ he says. â€œYouâ€™re inventing a core technology that can then be applied in many different ways.â€
The appâ€™s algorithms are focused on more than just tracking clicks and engagement. It weighs other factors, too, like dwell time, read time, shares, stories that get shared in DMs (private messages) and more.
â€œIf you let your algorithm focus on clicks, it will end up serving clickbait. If you simply optimize for only what people have clicked on, you end up having tunnel vision,â€ Systrom explains.
The model additionally involves an algorithm called Epsilon-Greedy.
â€œThatâ€™s a technical term for you taking some small portion of your time â€” like 10% or 20% â€” and you explore. You do something different than you would normally doâ€¦you go to the outside of the recommendation spectrum rather than the core of it,â€ Systrom says. â€œItâ€™s shown many, many times, especially in reinforcement learning, that having this â€˜exploreâ€™ budget weâ€™ll call it, actually is optimal for users.â€
Thatâ€™s the same reason why TikTok has begun testing tools that let users refresh their feeds. Without the added spice of unexpected content, the video appâ€™s suggestions had grown stale for some users.
But because the news changes every day, Artifactâ€™s use of this Epsilon-Greedy algorithm also has to adapt as usersâ€™ own interests in topics grow and wane. For example, someone might be very into reading about the upcoming elections up until Election Day has passed. Or a new story may immediately capture their attention when it comes out of nowhere, as the story about the Chinese spy balloon did.
Artifactâ€™s editorial consideration, if you can call it that, will also come into how the appâ€™s algorithm is programmed, not just its publisher selections.
â€œActually, building the algorithm is enormously editorial,â€ Systrom says. â€œBecause what you choose to train your algorithm on â€” the objective function, the data you put in, the data you include, the data you donâ€™t include â€” is all in editorial judgment. The way you weight different objectives.â€
â€œAll of the edge a company has is in its ability to wrangle the data in such a way that produces an outcome thatâ€™s optimal,â€ Systrom says.
If anything is Artifactâ€™s secret sauce, itâ€™s that.
Does Artifact have a future?
Whether all this tech and â€œtasteâ€ is enough for Artifact to succeed remains to be seen. The U.S. news aggregation landscape is not like Chinaâ€™s. And here, Artifact will have to fight against the default ways people access news, including through the news apps that come bundled with their smartphones, as well as the large internet portals like Google and Facebook, and some extent, YouTube and TikTok too.
At launch, Artifact added new functionality, including a new feature that allows users to track how theyâ€™ve been engaging with the app and its content in a metrics section, which shows a list of publishers and topics theyâ€™ve been reading. Over time, Artifact plans to let users adjust which topics they want to see more and less of, or even block publishers.
Theyâ€™ll also later be able to socialize through comment threads around the stories themselves, in what could be a stealth competitor to Twitter â€” an app thatâ€™s seen a small exodus in the wake of Elon Muskâ€™s takeover. (In fact, Artifact just added a feature similar to Twitterâ€™s with its ability to show you articles trending in your network, if you sync your contacts to the service.)

As for Artifactâ€™s future, Systrom says he hopes it will eventually become a place where users can go, first and foremost, to discover content around their interests and be able to discuss them with others.
That said, itâ€™s still immeasurably hard for a new consumer app to gain traction without fueling customer acquisition costs with buckets of money. But one thing the team learned from building Instagram, is that Facebook can be a useful tool for gaining adoption. Many of its first users found the app by way of Instagram photos posted to Facebook.

Heâ€™s not all that worried that this would have him wading into Facebookâ€™s territory, which to some represents an unbeatable giant.

The question is whether or not people choose to attack it and if the right people choose to attack it. I could have never predicted that Snapchat would have risen during Instagram, which obviously had a stronghold on images and social â€” there was no way to predict there was an opening there. Thereâ€™s no way to predict that TikTok would have come about when Snap and Instagram were so big. I think these things are far more random than you think.â€
These changes tend to be around fundamental changes in technology, like the interest graph, Systrom says.
But, he adds, â€œI do think we see this wave of machine learning right now that opens up an enormous window to do new things in social.â€
